editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Love at a Venture. A COMEDY. As it is ACTED By his Grace, the Duke of Grafton's Servants, AT THE NEW THEATRE IN BATH.
Written by the Author of the Gameſter.
LONDON: Printed for John Chantry, at the Sign of Lincolon's-Inn-Square, at Lincolons-Inn-Back-Gate, 1706. Price 1s. 6d.

div.head: To his Grace, Henry Duke of Beaufort, Marquiſs and Earl of Worceſter, Baron Herbert of Gower, Rawland, Chepſtow, &c.
div.p:
IT has been a general, and allow'd Cuſtom, in all Ages, for Poets, to lay their Works at ſome Great Man's Feet, and always to chuſe ſuch as are eminently Conſpicuous for their Vertues. This made Horace ſingle out Mecenas, and Terence court the Protection of Scipio and Lelius; which encourages me, in humble Imitation of thoſe Great Men, to beg your Grace's Pratronage for the following Scenes. It would be a kind of Poetical Sacrilege to offer them elſe where, ſince it wou'd rob your Grace of the Homage, to which your Quality, Senſe, and good Nature, your Indulgence to Poetry, and your Judgment as well as Love for Muſick, give you an indiſputable Title. Muſick is the Soul of Poeſy, and
Numbers ſound moſt ſweet, when grac'd with ſoft harmonious Strains.

I am the more forward, to pay this juſt Debt, My Lord, becauſe without the help of Fiction, conſequently without the help of Flattery, I have a large Field for a Panegyrick; which, however, I ſhall prudently decline, for fear of degrading your Vertues through my Inability and Meanneſs of Expreſſion. Yet I cannot forbear mentioning the Excellency of your Grace's Temper, your Goodneſs and Affability, and the Regard you have for that generous Cuſtom, which formerly diſtinguiſh'd the Engliſh Nation, from all the reſt of the World, viz. Hoſpitality: which makes your Grace admired, and beloved to a degree, next Adoration, by all, who are ſo happy as to approach you.

Your Grace, is a true Pattern of Nobility: The prudent Management of your Affairs; your Voluntary Retreat from Noiſe and Vice, ſhew you have a right Conception of the Joys of Life, as Cowley has deſcrib'd them. To favour your Retirement, Nature ſeems to have taken peculiar Care to indulge your Grace's Solitude, with all her choice Productions: For your Gardens exceed all that Poets feign.

That your Grace, may long enjoy thoſe Bleſſings in perfect Health, and unmoleſted Peace, together with your Beauteous Lady; and that your Connubial Joys may produce a perfect Copy of their Parents, which may adorn the Age to come, with the ſame Singularity of Goodneſs, as your Grace does the preſent; are, My Lord, the ſincere Wiſhes of,

closer.signed: Your Graces, moſt Obedient, moſt Devoted, Humble Servant, Suſanna Carroll.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: LEaſt any here ſhou'd blame our Author's toil,
For ſtroling with her Boat a Hundred Mile.
By me to ſuch, She does this Reaſon give,
Seeing how many Men by Ventures live.
She ſtraight embark'd, and hoiſted Sail to try,
What pure good Nature in theſe Bottoms lye.
Beſide, ſhe hop'd, ſhe might divert you too,
By adding to your Pleaſures ſomething new.
The Vertue of theſe Baths had ne're been known,
If or'e theſe Hills, no Man had ventur'd down.
Here Doctors Venturing, come in hopes of Fees,
And Patients Venture, on their Skill for Eaſe,
For Wealth, the Merchant Ventures on the Seas.
The Lawyer Ventures upon any Cauſe,
And Venturing Client's begger'd by the Laws.
The Lover Ventures, to Addreſs the Fair,
With broken Speeches, and dejected Air,
She runs a Venture, who relieves his care.
The Gameſter Ventures, to improve his Store,
And having loſt, he Ventures on for more.
The London Punk, in Garret ſhut all Day,
At Night, with laſt half Crown ſhe Ventures to the Play.
The Amorous Cully, meeting with the Miſs,
Ventures at Water-Gruel for a Kiſs.
Since every Man, Adventures in his way,
Hither our Author ventur'd with her Play.
And hopes her Profits will her Charge defray,
If that bright Circle Ventures to adorn her Day.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
div.l: IN ſpight of dull inſipid Rules, I'm come,
To learn what Fate attends my Virgin Bloom.
Strange things I've heard this Night, that makes me fear,
Leaſt I ſhou'd find ſuch Entertainment here.
You Men are grown ſo witty in Deceit,
That We, poor Girls, are often ruin'd by't.
'Tis pitty—but I hope to croſs this Play,
And be reveng'd on you ſome other way.
Well—but conſider, We are tender Things,
That Innocence, and ſprightly Beauty brings.
Soft Accents, broken Words, and yielding Air,
Are all the Weapons, that attend the Fair.
And can you long reſiſt, the ſweet Temptation,
Give us at leaſt a Bill of Reformation.
That the ſucceeding Age may ſay of you,
You dare be Civil, tho' you can't be true.
But if at laſt no Charms have power to win-ye,
You're paſt Repentance—or the Devil's in-ye.

list.item: Belair,—A Gentleman juſt come from Travel; an Airy Spark.
Sir William Freelove,—Friend to Belair, in Love with Beliza.
Sir Paul Cautious—A Whimſical, Deſponding, Old Fellow.
Ned Freelove,—Younger Brother to Sir William.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Lady Coutious,—Wife to Sir Paul, and Siſter to Sir William.
Camilla,—Couſin to Beliza, a great Fortune.

head.hi: Sir Paul Cautious's Houſe. Sir William Freelove's Apartment.

div.stage: Enter Bellair and Robin, meeting Sir William.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: OH! Sir William, I am ſo tranſported, I cannot ſpeak in the common ſtrain of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: And prethy, Bellair, What occaſions this Tranſport?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Had'ſt thou been my profeſt Enemy all thy Life, and done me as much miſchief as the Turk in Hungary, or the French in Flanders; if thou'lt but help me now, thou woud'ſt make amends for all—ſuch a Creature!—ſuch an Angel!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What Viſions! Aparitions?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Cou'd I but hope to ſee her once more, I'd change the happieſt half of my Life for that one moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: If you pleaſe to deſcend from your high flown Raptures, and walk hand in hand with my Underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You'l lead me to her. (haſtily.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what, before I know where ſhe is—you wou'd be landed at your Port before you have taken Shipping, or told the place you deſign for.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pho; you know all my Deſigns.

sp.speaker: Robin,
sp.p: When a Woman's concern'd (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Are Extravagant—you have more Intreagues upon your Hands, than a handſom young Poet on the ſucceſs of his firſt Play—like a Dog in a Herd, you run at all, and catch none, becauſe you run with ſuch ungovern'd Heat, you ſpring the Quarry before you can draw your Net.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But if I miſs Sitting, I commonly hit 'em Flying—but this is nothing to the purpoſe; the Lady, Man, the Lady—.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, the Lady; what of her?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Which I ſaw laſt Night—Oh, ſuch a Creature!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: At what Window?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Such a Charming Air.—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What Houſe was it at?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As much Youth as wou'd ſerve to recover half the decay'd Faces in the Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What Street?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Wanton as a Nun, yet look'd demure as a Quaker—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Z'death, where, where, is this rare Creature to be ſeen?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then her Features, Sir William! Oh, ſuch Features; ſhe is the moſt perfect Piece in the World—her ſhape clean and eaſy—a profuſe quantity of dark brown Hair—and ſuch a Complexion, as the Gods form when they deſign a Miracle of Beauty.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Nay, ſince you will have your own way, I'll ſtrike in with you—a charming high Forehead.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, and ſuch a Mouth—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Sparkling Black Eyes—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And ſuch a Caſt—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Such Dimples in her Cheeks—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Rapture, Rapture.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ah, he's got above the Clouds already—when you have recover'd your Senſes, Bellair, you may be fit for Converſation; I have a little buſineſs to diſpatch—and muſt beg your Pardon.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou wilt not leave me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, what Service can I do you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You muſt aſſiſt me in the Management of this Affair.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What Affair? Who is ſhe? Where did you ſee her?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why, when I left you laſt Night, I took a Boat reſolving to go up the River for a little Air, when the luckieſt occaſion preſented to make me the happieſt Man living.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I have known a hundred of theſe lucky Occaſions; in a Months time the moſt unlucky Occaſions, that ever Man had. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Lady deſigning to Land at White-Hall Stairs, ſtepping ſhort from the Boat, fell into the Water, I jumpt in after her, caught her in my Arms, and brought her ſafe a-ſhoar.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Who cou'd have believ'd he ſhou'd be burnt in the middle of the Thames now.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What's her Name?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I know not, ſhe enquir'd mine, and where I liv'd; gave me a thouſand Thanks, and promis'd I ſhou'd hear from her.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, and what can I do for you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
I'll tell you, I muſt have Lodgings in this Houſe, for here I directed her; told her my Name was Conſtant, tho', faith, Bellair was at my Tongues end; but you know my Reaſons for concealing my Name, leaſt my Father hear I'm in England, before I'd have him, and force me to marry the Woman he commanded me Home for, which, for ought I know, may be Ugly, Old, Ill-natur'd, Fooliſh, Conceited, Vain, and ſo forth—at leaſt, I ſhall think
her ſuch, becauſe of his chuſing—I like no Caterer in Love's Market—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You ſhall have theſe Lodgings to oblige you, good Mr. Conſtant—but what have you done with the other Lady you told me of yeſterday; you was then dying for her?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith, I like her ſtill—but t'other, t'other, is a perfect Venus—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what is your Name to her? I ſhall certainly forget all theſe Names—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Colonel Revel, you Sot.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Juſt come from where, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: From Portugal, Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And—are you an—Officer too in t'other Place with your new Amour; Co, co, co, con, pray, Sir, do me the favour to tell me your Name to this Incognita once more?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Conſtant, Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And what are you, Sir, pray, what are you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: An Oxfordſhire Gentleman; remember that, Sirrah, come up to Town about a Law-Suit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—Colonel Revell juſt come from Portugal—Mr. Conſtant, an Oxfordſhire Gentleman, come up about a Law-Suit—Very well, I have it now, Sir, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, but do you think to manage both theſe Intreagues with Secrecy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I do; and in order to't, I'll keep my own Lodgings, that are known to the other, and theſe for my Incognita, and I'll engage to play my part with both.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: To what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why, ſince my old Dad will have me Marry, I would willingly chuſe for my ſelf; now, you muſt know, I deſign to take my ſwing of Love and Liberty—if, in the chaſe, I chance to meet one that can fix me, her I'll Marry; till when I'll, like the Bee, kiſs every Plant, and gather ſweatneſs from every Flower—Youth is the Harveſt of our Lives, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, in my Conſcience, Travel has given thee a large Aſſurance.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, here is Mr. Wou'dbe to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who's he?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: The Projecting Coxcomb, I told you of Yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What, he that Mimicks thee in his Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: The ſame—now, for hard Words, and ſoft Senſe; bring him up.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'll not ſtay—I expect a Meſſage from my t'other Miſtreſs at my Lodgings; I'll ſend a Night-Gown, and a ſuit of Cloths hither; and Robin ſhall wait to call me, if my fair Unknown ſends—Oh the Pleaſure of Intreague; it finds Employment for every Senſe, ſharpens the Wit, and gives a life to all our Faculties.

l.hi: When pal'd with one, another ſtill ſupplies,
Thus different Women gives us different Joys.
Beauty in one; in t'other Wit we find;
In this a Shape, in that a ſpacious Mind;
But change, dear change, thou Life of human kind.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Dear, Sir William, my Stars are ſuperabundantly propitious, in adminiſtring the ſeraphick Felicity of finding you alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Wou'dbe—ſpare me, I beſeech you—

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: My Soul's inhabited; or, rather Canoniz'd, with an Alacrity to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I know not how his Soul's inhabited; but his Head might paſs for a Colony, in Greenland, it is ſo thinly Peopled. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Brother, good Morrow; Mr. Wou'dbe, yours.

sp.speaker: Wou'db.
sp.p: Sir, I am moſt obſequiouſly your Servant.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: What Gentleman was that I ſaw go out juſt now?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
A Friend of mine, who, for ſome reaſons, I have promis'd this Appartment to; I hope Sir Paul won't be
alarm'd; I think 'tis beſt not to let him know it, if he does not find it out.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Much the beſt, for he'l ask ſo many impertinent Queſtions about him, and be in ſuch a fright; he'l call in half the Pariſh to watch with him—Who is the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: If you remember, I told you, when I was in Spain, a Gentleman reſcu'd me from the hands of Ruffians, when I was ſet upon in the Night; this is he, and ever ſince we have held a ſtrickt Friendſhip—Perhaps he may have kill'd his Man, I know not; he deſires privacy—and I am bound, in honour, to give it.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Doubtleſs—What's his Name?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the Taylor has brought home your Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Bring him in.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: But, Sir William, pray, how do you like my Way of greeting—I never want Words, you ſee—I hate thoſe dull Rogues, that have no better Expreſſions at meeting their Friends than, dear Jack, how is't? [Enter Taylor, and Sir William dreſſes] Meer Fuſtin—ha! What do I ſee? Another Suit—and, upon my veracity, a Charming one—I muſt put down the Triming exactly, I ſhall obliterate half elſe. [Takes out a Book and Writes.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Our Engliſh Tongue is much oblig'd to you, Mr. Wou'dbe.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Is it not too ſhort, Mr. Meaſure? (To the Taylor.)

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Not at all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: The Suit my Taylor is making, is the very ſame Colour; I'll ſend, and have it Trim'd exactly like that. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: How do you like my fancy in this Suit, Mr. Wou'dbe?

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Sir William, I reverence the ſublimity of your Fancy—If mine be not done by Play-time, I'll break my Tayler's Head, and never pay the Bill. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: But what new Diſcoveries have you made lately, Mr. Wou'dbe? Never a Project, ha!

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I am going to erect an Office for Poetry.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: How! An Office for Poetry?

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, where all Poets may have free acceſs, paying ſuch a moiety of their Profits, and be furniſh'd with all ſorts of Refin'd Words adapted to their ſeveral Characters.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: The Poets will be very much oblig'd to you truly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: I think ſo—hark ye, I'm upon another Project, which you'll not gueſs for a Wager?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, really, Mr. Wou'dbe; 'tis not in my ſhallow Capacity, to fathom the profundity of your Wit.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Oh, Sir William, ſuch accumulated Kindneſs will Bankrupt my poor Acknowledgments—profundity of your Wit—ſpoke like a Gentleman, and a Scholar—thou art expenſively obliging, therefore I will Communicate—tho' it is not grown to a full Maturity, yet—'tis this—for the good of the Publick, I am contriving how to ſave the charges of Hackney-Coaches; the Raſcals are ſo ſaucy, eſpecially to Ladies, there's no enduring them; I reſolve to deſtroy their Conſtitution.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: As how, prethee?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: They are the moſt neceſſary things in the World; a Hackney-Coach carries us from one end of the Town to the other in a trice.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Ay, Sir William—but my Project carries 'em quicker—and without go, ng out of their Houſes.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: That's a Stratagem, indeed, beyond my Comprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: If you can do that, Mr. Wou'dbe, you need not fear a Patent; the Ladies will be all of your ſide.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: They will have reaſon, Sir, for they may Dreſs, Patch, Paint, drink Tea, or play at Piquet, all the while they are going to the Play-houſe—Is not this an excellent Project?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Excellent, indeed; but, prethee, how is it?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ay, ay, how is it, you muſt deal with the Devil certainly.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: No, without his help, I aſſure you, 'tis all my own—this individual Brain contriv'd it—were I known at Court, I ſhou'd be a great Man—a moſt magnificent Man.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Oh, this Project, Sir, will do your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: I know you are impatient for the Secret; you are my Friends, or I'd not impart a matter of this Conſequence.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I hope you don't doubt our ſecrecy?

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt—to convince you, 'tis this, I'll make the Streets to move.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha, ha, the Streets move! Prethee, how will thou do that?

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Oh, by Clock-Work, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: By Clock-Work? What, make the ſolid Earth move by Clock-Work?

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Ay, Sir—I affirm that's poſſible—You miſtake, the Earth is not ſolid; read but Baker's Chronicle, and you'll find a whole Field walk'd ten mile in Queen Beſs's days.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: But not by Clock-Work, Mr VVou'dbe.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p:
Humph—ha—I can't be poſitive in that, but—if it can walk at all—why can't it be made walk by Clock-work—but in a Months time I ſhall be able to anſwer that, and all other Objections—For, you muſt know, Yeſterday I began my Study, in order to ſearch out the Curioſity of every Country, Language, Art and Science—you ſhall hear how I have Canton'd out the Day—I riſe about Five. my firſt hour is laid out upon Law—'tis fit a Gentleman ſhou'd underſtand the Laws of his Country, tho' I hate the confounded Study, 'tis ſo crabbed—At Six. I read a Leſſon of Greek—at Seven, one of Hebrew—Eight, is for Italian—Nine, for Spaniſh—Ten,
for French—Eleven Aſtronomy—Twelve is proper for Geography, then the Sun Beams are perpendicular—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Excellent, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: At One I Dine—then Repoſe an Hour, for Digeſtion—at Three I Study Phyſick—that, if I'm Poiſon'd by the Vintners, I may not be kill'd by the Doctors—at Four Logick—at Five Phyloſophy—at Six Husbandry—that when my Father dies, my Steward, and Tenants, may't cheat me—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: A Politick thought—

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: Hawking, Hunting, Fiſhing, Fowling, at Seven—Architecture at Eight—for to underſtand the Art of Building, is of mighty conſequence towards raiſing of a Man's Fortune, you know—Nine for Poetry, in honour of the Nine Muſes—becauſe I love the Ladies Company towards Bed-time—Thus, in a Month, I hope to become Maſter of all theſe things; how like you my Rules, Gentlemen, ha?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Oh, wonderfully, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: Well, Poetry is one of the nobleſt Parts of the Mathematicks—but we have ſuch Factions now on foot, that Muſick has put Poetry quite out of Tune—but that Suit—I muſt to my Taylor immediately— (aſide.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: But, Mr. VVou'dbe, the Town ſay you are much in Beleiza's favour—you won't Rival my Brother, will you?

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: Not I, upon my Soul—but does the Town really ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Why ſhou'd I tell you ſo elſe?

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: Nay, the Elegance of my Fabrick, has Titulated the Imagination of many a fine Lady, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, the Fool believes you.

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: Where do you Dine, Sir VVilliam?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: With my Siſter Cautious.

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p:
If Beliza likes me—I'm a happy Mortal; I'll make ſome advance, and give her to underſtand I'm not
inexorable (aſide) I'll Rendezvouſe you at the Portal of her Apartment after Dinner; your moſt Obſequious—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: He took particular Notice of your Cloths, Brother; I'll venture a Guinea, the next time he appears, he's Equipt to a Hair, if either Money or Credit be in his Power; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: I believe that, but I'll give him enough on't if he is—'tis the moſt Whimſical Coxcomb I ever ſaw—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Well, but how goes it between you and Beliza, Brother?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: I begin to doubt a Rival there, but who, I can't find out—She is grown indifferent of late, often abroad, and ſeldom in humour, when at home; if there be a Favourite in reſerve, let her take care to conceal him, for, Faith, I have ſuck'd in the Spaniard's Jealouſy with their Air, and ſhou'd breath a Vain without ſcruple—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Well, if ever I be in Love—of all Paſſions which agitate the mind of Man—grant I may never be infected with Jealouſy.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Thou prayeſt againſt the only thing that gives Love a reliſh.

l.hi: Love, like to Luſcious Meat, will Surfeits breed,
And hurt the Stomach which th'are Sent to feed.
VVithout a grain of Jealouſy apply'd,
Your Appetite, your Health, and Life's deſtroy'd.

head.hi: The Scene Changes to Bellair's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I foreſee this Day, Mrs. Patch, will be a Lucky-day—the ſight of thee—

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Will not pleaſe you, I dare be poſitive, my Lady can't ſee you to Day, being oblig'd to go abroad.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, propitious diſingagement—Now, if my Incognita does but ſend— (aſide.) I'll wait for her return, let it be never ſo late—

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Not to day, ſweet Sir—your love runs on Wheels—Pray, more ſoftly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This Girl's very Pritty, I never minded her ſo much before—Hark ye, Child, I will come, if I miſs thy Lady, thou ſhalt keep me Company.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: You are merry, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I muſt be ſo, when I'm near any thing—belonging to Beliza—Methinks I entertain her, whilſt thou art near me.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I can't tell how you mean it, Sir—but I aſſure you, as fine Gentlemen as your ſelf, have paid their Devotions to me, before now—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why not? he muſt be Inſenſible, that ſo much Beauty cannot warm. (Kiſſes her.)

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Why, the Devil's in my Maſter—agad, I ſhall ſtarve with him in Love's Kitchin, for he Engroſſes all ſorts of Fleſh, I find. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Not ſo cloſe, I beſeech you, Sir. (puſhing him away.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I proteſt my Heart feels a thouſand Emotions for thee—

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Pray ſtop your Emotions, Sir—and don't load me with your Heart, for I have ſo many already I don't know where to put 'em, without choaking one another.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: She need never fear that, he'l not ſtay ſo long—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I proteſt it is a pleaſure to look on thee—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: He does not love to be idle, I'll ſay that for him; but I bring him Imployment, and muſt diſturb him—Sir.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I am not ſurpriz'd at that—for I take pleaſure to look on my ſelf, and generally do it a thouſand times a day.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir,—Sir,—Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha! has ſhe ſent?(aſide to Robin.)

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: The Maid ſtays for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! Tranſport—run—fly, let every thing be ready for my change of Dreſs, I'll be there in an Inſtant—I wiſh this Girl were gon.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: So, the Tide's turn'd already—Why, what a hurrying Life's this I lead

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Well, what more fine things, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, I ſee you don't believe what I have ſaid already—and an, an—piſh pox—how ſhall I get rid of her—

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: You are out of humour, Sir, I hope, I—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, no, no, no, Child, I, I, I—what the Divel ſhall I ſay—this is the moſt unlucky accident.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: What is, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A good hint—why, my Man tells me there is a Friend of mine wounded in a Duel, and deſires me to bring a Surgeon immediately—ſo dear little Rogue, excuſe me, this kiſs to thy Lady, and tell her Revel Lives not in her abſence—if this don't do't, I ſhall go diſtracted, that's certain— (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Nay, I have done my Meſſage, ſo, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, now for my dear unknown—Let me ſee, what am I?—ho, a Country Gentleman—I muſt reſtrain my humour—a little quantity will be neceſſary to adorn that Character—beſides, the Inventions new, and gives the Intreague the greater Guſto—

l.hi: To gain my Point, I'll every Art improve,
All Policy's allow'd in War and Love.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: AND you are really in Love with this Stranger, Couſin?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I fear ſo, Beliza.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: To what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To no purpoſe at all, without thy help.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: You are aſſur'd of me—but, prithee, in what can I help thee? You neither know who he is, nor what he is—he may, for ought you know, be a Wretch unworthy of your Eſteem.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Impoſſible—I tell thee, he's a Country Gentleman, which the Term brought up to Town on Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Then, how are you ſure he is not married in the Country?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Start no Objections, I beſeech you—I am ſure he is not married—he did not look as if he was.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Well, ſuppoſe he is what you'd have him be, you know your Father has diſpos'd of you, and I'm affraid won't be prevail'd upon to alter his Mind.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ay, there's the only Bar to all my wiſhes; why ſhou'd our Parents impoſe upon our Inclinations, in that one Choice which makes us ever Happy, or ever Miſerable?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: 'Tis an unjuſt Prerogative Parents have got, from whence I ſee no deliverance without an Act of Parliament.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If thou art my Friend, Beliza, I may chance to Croſs my Father's Deſign, without the help of the Senate.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: I confeſs I am a well-wiſher to Diſobedience in Love Affairs—there's my hand, inſtruct me how I may be ſerviceable.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Thus! I have ſent Flora to give him an Invitation hither—

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Hither!—to my Lodgings; 'tis well I ſent Colonel Revel word I ſhou'd not be at home. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Yes, I hope you'l forgive the Liberty I have taken, I was not willing he ſhou'd know mine, till I have your Approbation of him.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: But how if my Lover, Sir William, ſhou'd happen to come, who is grown a perfect Spaniard ſince his Travels, and has of late been apprehenſive of a Rival, tho' from what cauſe I know not—the Country Gentleman wou'd be in danger, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To prevent his being ſeen, I have order'd him to be brought in the Back-way—he is yet a ſtranger to every thing that concerns me—he neither knows my Name nor Family—nor ſhall he, if you approve him not; therefore, after I have thank'd him for the Service he did me, I'll give him to underſtand I have a Relation whoſe Judgment I rely on—and from her Mouth he muſt receive his hopes, then I'll call you in and retire.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: You have a very good Opinion of me, Couſin.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I have ſo.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He waits your pleaſure, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Bring him in—Couſin, you'l be at Hand.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: In the next Room.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is an Honour ſo much above my Merit, Madam—that I receive it with Conſuſion, and ſhall be uneaſy till you inform me, how I may return this wonderous Favour—I am caught by Venus, what Eyes are there—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
Rather inſtruct me, Sir, how I may return the Obligations I have to you; they are no common Ones—
you purchas'd my Life at the hazard of your own, and it ſhall be the buſineſs of that Life you ſav'd (if ever ought falls within my Power) to ſerve you. Oh, my Heart. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: On that kind Promiſe will I build my hopes; nay, I will rely upon it—and now, Madam, I muſt declare that it is in your Power to over-pay the Hazard you have mention'd; the only Woman I cou'd be content to take, for Better for Worſe, I ever ſaw; egad, I'm upon the very precipice of Matrimony, if ſhe conſents (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Gratitude obliges generous Souls—then be aſſur'd, and ask—pray Heaven his Deſigns be Honourable—that he asks the right. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis done, faith, (aſide.) your Heart—I fear you'l think I am too bold in my deſires—but you commanded me to ſpeak—and I durſt not tell you a Lye—your ſelf wou'd have diſcover'd it, for your Beauteous Image is drawn ſo lively in my Breaſt, that you are Miſtreſs of every Thought, and every Wiſh about it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: My Soul tells him, thro' my Eyes, (I fear) that his requeſt is granted, (aſide) I confeſs you have ſurpriz'd me, Sir, and I know not well what to Anſwer you; only this—were I free to diſpoſe of my Perſon, with my Heart, your Services ſhou'd not go unrewarded.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha! what ſay you, Madam! your words ſhake me like an Ague Fit—you are not—(forbid it Heaven) Married?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Not Married.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nor vow'd againſt it?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Neither—but I've a Father to whom my Duty muſt ſubmit, without his leave I meaſure not a Foot of his Eſtate, tho' I'm his only Child.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let him keep it then, if Love had any Power o'er your Soul—or had I Charms to Wound like you, this wou'd be no Obſtacle.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You have too many, and I find my Heart but too inclining—were it poſſible, but my Duty—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, extafy, I ſhan't contain my ſelf (aſide) it is, it ſhall be poſſible—give me to underſtand your Father, Madam, that I may apply my ſelf to him; if Avarice affects him, and Wealth be his only aim, I am Heir to an Eſtate, perhaps, as large as he can wiſh.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But, how are your ſure your Father will conſent; and why wou'd you hazard his Diſpleaſure for a Stranger, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Eſtate's intail'd, he cannot hurt me there, and here I muſt be happy, or not at all—may I not know your Family?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Yet, you muſt not.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why ſhou'd you deny me—Is it not in my power to know—Can I not inquire when I go out, whoſe Houſe this is?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Without any benefit by it—for theſe are a Friend's Lodgings, whoſe Judgment I eſteem, you ſhall conſult her; if ſhe approves it, perhaps, you may know mine before Night—Who's there?
Deſire Beliza to Walk in—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha! Did ſhe not name Beliza? I hope it is not that Beliza I know—if it ſhou'd, I'm in a fine condition— [Enter Beliza and Patch.] by ill Luck—the very ſhe,—what the Devil ſhall I do? (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Couſin, this is the Gentleman I'm ſo much oblig'd to—Mr. Conſtant, this is a Relation of mine.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: What do I ſee? Colonel Revell here—

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis even he.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There is no excuſe to be made now—thou never failing Power of Impudence aſſiſt me. (aſide.) I muſt Honour every thing that's Related to you, Madam. (Salutes her.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: How grave he is this diſguiſe—picques me, methinks, tho' I had no deſign upon him.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: How ſober he looks—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: This is the Friend I refer you to, Mr. Conſtant.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Conſtant!—Yes, he is Conſtant with a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p: What ſhe promiſes I'll confirm.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'm in a hopeful way, faith—egad, I am ſo confounded, I know not how to look—but I'm reſolv'd to carry it off, and perſwade her I'm not the Man. (aside.) Madam, I'm oblig'd to my Stars, however, tho' they conceal the Family, and Name of her I adore, they g ••• me an opportunity of knowing her ſecond ſelf, you being made ſo by the ſtricteſt bonds of Friendſhip—this is the hardeſt task I ever went thro', by Jupiter. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: I don't wonder that you know me—but I am ſurpriz'd at your Impudence.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: This is the firſt time I was ever accus'd of that by a fair Lady; Wherein have I incurr'd your diſpleaſure?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, do you act this part upon a Wager, or do you think I have loſt my Senſes—very pritty, truly—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Wager—Part—and Senſes—What do you mean, Madam?—Oh, miſchievous encounter. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Colonel Revel can inform Mr. Conſtant of my meaning.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Colonel Revell! who's he?—a Pox of the Name. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: So, he don't know himſelf—

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: You don't know ſuch a Man, as Colonel Revell▪

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not I, upon my word, Madam—

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Well, ſuch an Aſſurance, I never ſaw, and do you think this will paſs upon me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I hope ſo, (aſide.) I proteſt, Madam, I can't gueſs what you aim at—

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Were I in your place, Madam, I'd have him toſt in a Blanket.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Mrs. Patch; egad, wou'd I were well out of their hands. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, your Declaration for my Couſin concerns me not; ſor, from the firſt, to me you appear'd as indifferent as now—But if you think to impoſe upon my Underſtanding, you'l draw my utmoſt Malice on your Head.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And I need no more—for the malice of a Woman, exceeds the Devils; (aſide.) Your Rallery is very pleaſant, Madam; but very different from what I expected—for, I confeſs, I am a Stranger to your meaning.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Oh, you ſhift your Shape ſo often, you may eaſily forget—an excellent Contrivance, to take as many Names, as you make Miſtreſs's.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Conſult your Pocket-Book, Sir; and you'l find your Name was, Revell, two hours ago—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is a new way of Treating Strangers, Madam; do you call this, telling me the Secrets of the Unknown Fair; this will make the prittieſt Novel, in the World— (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: The Secrets of the Unknown Fair; yes, She ſhall know your Secrets, I'll promiſe you, and who you are—believe me, your Affairs are done with her; you ſhall neither know her Name, nor Quality.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Recal that Sentence, Madam; Or, let me fall a Sacrifice, to your ſuppoſed Reſentments—never to know my Lovely, Dear Incognita, is Death, with all the additional Racks Barbarians e're invented, to ſeparate Soul and Body. I begin to grow perfect in my double Art, I find. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: This is the moſt Bare-fac'd Impoſtor I ever ſaw. (aſide.) Really now, in my opinion, Colonel, you act the ſame Perſon too long—come, come, pull off the Maſque, and I'll forgive you, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That wheedle ſhan't take, I'm in, and muſt go thro' it, (aſide) Mask, Madam! by all the pangs of Love I feel for your Beauteous Friend, I wou'd wear no diſguiſe to any thing that belongs to her—

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Well, was I my Lady, I'd have that Tongue pull'd out of your Head.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, who is that pritty Enemy; is ſhe Friend, or ſome Relation?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Do, do, ſeem Ignorant, poor Devil—you don't know me; not long ſince, you knew me for this Lady's Maid, and lik'd me well enough, to think me worth a Compliment.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Make Love to my Woman! Pray, Sir, what Name wou'd you have taken to her, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You are in a pleaſant humour, Ladies; I hope I ſhall find the benefit of it; to my knowledge, I never ſaw any of you, till this hour—This is a Maſter-piece of Art, to face down two Women at once. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Nay, if I had believ'd all he ſaid to me, I ſhou'd have Regiſtred him amongſt my Lovers. That is not true, neither?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As the reſt—Poor, Gentlewoman, I pitty thee; prithy get Advice, before thy Frenzy increaſe too much.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: So, you'l perſwade us we are Mad, by and by—and you don't bear a Colonel's Commiſſion, and have not been in Portugal with Charles the Third?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, upon my honour, Madam—My Name is, Conſtant, born in Oxfordſhire, and come up about a Suit in Chancery; and know this Colonel no more, than you know me; if you pleaſe, I'll give you my Oath on't—which I can do without Perjury, that's my Comfort. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: A pleaſant quibble, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: This Story has coſt you ſome Pains—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I wiſh I cou'd ſee this Gentleman which you take me for; can you believe I cou'd be ſo baſe to make Love to another, if once I had preſum'd to mention it to you—your Charms are full ſecurity againſt ſuch Proceedings; I am concern'd, that Nature has made any reſemblance between us; I ſhall hate my ſelf for being like him.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Well, whether you will, or you will not be him, it is the ſame thing—provided you'l tell him, that I ſuffer'd his Addreſſes only for my Diverſion, and that I never had any Paſſion for him, but loath, deteſt and hate him?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Tell him—where ſhall I find him?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: I have done, and deſire you'd know your way out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I wou'd not willingly diſobey a Lady; but here, Madam, you muſt pardon me, ſince my future good or ill depends on you; I cannot ſtir from hence till I obtain your promiſe to aſſiſt my Suit, and give me hopes that I, at laſt, may know my Beauteous Fair.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
Pat.
sp.p: There's your Anſwer, Sir,—and if you pleaſe to follow me, I'll ſhew you a way out better known to you than that you came in by.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray, good Mrs. Civility, be not ſo haſty—give me leave, at leaſt, to ſee your Couſin before I go, Madam.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: To what end, pray?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To convince you of your Error.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: That's the hardeſt task that you ever undertook, Colonel, and not to be effected; therefore, once more I tell you, you have ſeen your laſt of her, and your abſence wou'd oblige me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis very hard, Madam, that becauſe nature has made me reſemble another Perſon, who may, for ought I know, be a Man of Honour too, tho' unhappily under your Diſpleaſure, I ſhou'd have the ill Fortune to ſuffer for Nature's Fault.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: That wou'd, indeed, be unjuſt—but I ſhall not be prevail'd upon to believe Nature in the fault here; therefore, pray retire, the Scene is long enough, 'tis time to change it; good Colonel, don't oblige one to treat you below your Title.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Don't you underſtand my Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Madam, but too well; and if I muſt go without the ſatisfaction I expected, let me implore this favour, tell her, I dye hers.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: And every bodies, I dare ſwear, in his turn.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: This Man, is the very Epitome of his Sex; the compleateſt Jugler I ever ſaw; I proteſt, his Aſſurance has put me quite out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Well, how do you like him, Couſin; is he not a Charming Fellow?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: I think not.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Piſh! I know you do.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Indeed, I don't; and if you knew as much as I, you wou'd think him as ugly as I do.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ugly! Can any mortal think that Man ugly? But, prithy, what have you diſcover'd—wou'nt you tell me?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Yes, if you promiſe to make right uſe on't.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: That your pretended Lover is a Villain.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: How! Pray, Couſin, Explain your Self within the Rules of good Manners.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: He deſerves it not.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you—and the Introduction grows tedious—of what do you accuſe Mr. Conſtant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In the firſt place, his Name is not Conſtant, but Revel.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: How know you that?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: From his own Mouth.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: A Week ago.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Here in this Houſe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: In this Houſe, how came he hither?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Upon his Legs, I think.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: On what Buſineſs, pray?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Much upon the ſame Errand—Love?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Love! To whom?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: To your Friend and Servant.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, now I find your Drift—you like him your ſelf, and this is an Artifice to blaſt my good Opinion—'tis poorly done, Beliza.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: No, my Conſtitution is not ſo warm as yours—remember you took Fire in the middle of Water; I diſpiſe him.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: We never diſpiſe indifferent things—I little expected this from a Friend.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: If you'd have the Friend continu'd, don't provoke me to return ſuſpicions, Couſin.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
Don't you provoke me, by traducing of the Man I love—he has not been in Town two days, and you'd perſuade
me he has made Overtures of Love to you a Week ago.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: If I don't prove this is Colonel Revel, lately come from Portugal, and been in Town this Fortnight, and made me ſeveral Viſits under pretence of Courtſhip A-la-mode, I'm content to forfeit both Friendſhip and Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: How ſhall it be prov'd? 'Tis ſure impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Write to him, and tell him what I have Confirm'd; deſire him to come hither to Juſtify himſelf, if he expects any farther Favours from you—at the ſame time I'll ſend for him by the Name of Revel, and appoint him here alſo, if there appear two Men exactly the ſame, (as I am ſure they are) then I'll own my ſelf in the Wrong, and ask your Pardon; if not, you ſhall mine.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Agreed, I'll in and write to him this moment; pray, Heaven, there be two Socia's.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I am pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: That's more than I am, I aſſure you, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: To find you alone, I meant, Madam; I am not ſurpriz'd at your being out of Humour, for I have ſeldom found you in it of late, the reaſon of which I'm yet to learn, not being Conſcious of having given you any Cauſe, except the trueſt Paſſion that e'er poſſeſs'd the Heart of Man be one.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Sometimes, and in ſome Perſons it is ſo; but from whence you derive your ſuſpitions, I can't imagine.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: From your exceſſive coldneſs—for ſome days paſt, I have beheld ſuch a reſerve in all your Carriage to me, very different from what it us'd to be, and I begun to fear your Heart had entertain'd ſome new Amour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I hope he has not diſcover'd this Impoſtor, he could not meet him, ſure. (aſide.) you have no reaſon to doubt my Sincerity, Sir William; I'm not Subject to fall in Love, I may venture to ſay, you hold the greateſt ſhare in my Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
That's kind—but this thin airy Dyet of Hope and Expectation, Beliza, ſtarve thoſe which feed on't—will
you not admit me to the Banquet of Poſſeſſion—when ſhall I receive from this hand the Confirmation of thoſe Lips. (kiſſes her Hand.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: When I can bring my Heart to a Reſolution, Sir William, of quitting all theſe little innocent Pleaſures, a ſingle Life permits, you ſhall have timely notice for a Licenſe.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Madam, your Couſin Camilla deſires one Word with you.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Pardon my leaving you in my own Lodgins, Sir William, ſome Affairs of my Couſins, who is lately come to Town, preſs me at preſent; I ſhall come to Cards at Lady Cautious's in the Evening.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I'll not fail being at home—there's ſomething more in this than I can Fathom; I reſolve to watch her narrowly, if I have a Rival, and ſcapes me, I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: IN Tears, Siſter? What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p:
What ſhou'd be the matter, but my Husband? that doating, old, diſpounding Wretch, whoſe Fears, Miſtruſts and Jealouſies, is enough to diſtract any Body, ſtill doubting Providence, and fearing every Wind—yet you are ſo far from pittying my Condition, you add to my
Misfortunes, by making my Confinement ſtricter, under pretence of the Honour of our Family—I hope I'm of Age to know how far that concerns me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, Siſter, but the Wife that is diſpleas'd with the Husband—and the Husband that does not pleaſe the Wife, are always in Danger—ſhe of liking ſome body elſe—and he of being a Cuckold—now, while there is ſuch a probability, the Honour of our Family requires a Guard.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Why was I marry'd then to that I cannot Love?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: My Father knew his Reaſons doubtleſs, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Yes, and I know 'em too—Sir Paul took me without a Fortune, by which yours is the greater, yet the conſideration has no weight with you; it pleaſes you to ſee your Siſter Condemn'd to the idle Fancies, and whimſical Miſtruſts, of this impertinent Doatard; he is ſo apprehenſive of Death, that he allows a Surgeon a Hundred a Year perpetually to attend him, and wou'd not ſet a ſtep without him for a Thouſand—nay, he lyes in the ſame Chamber—juſt now he fancied himſelf call'd three times, which he takes for an Omen of his Death, pray Heaven it prove ſo—and has ſent for Twenty People to watch by him.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ridiculous folly—but you muſt bear with it, Siſter; he is Old—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: That's the worſt Argument under the Sun, for a young Woman to bear with (aſide.) pray. Brother, what Gentleman is that which you have oblig'd with theſe Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ha! has ſhe ſeen him?—Why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Is it a Crime. to ask who is in my own Houſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, if they are not in your own Appartment—'tis not Modeſty in your Sex to inquire after ours—now I foreſee my Error too late, in letting him have theſe Lodgings—How came you to know there was a Man here?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I muſt not ſay, I have ſeen him— (aſide) my Woman brought me word, there was a Stranger dreſing himſelf, when I ſent her this Morning, to ask if you wou'd not drink ſome Chocolate with me.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Then, you did not ſee him your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear that, for he is Libertine enough to engage her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe I had, where had been the Crime?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Nay, no Crime, Siſter—only I wou'd not have you affronted; therefore, pray take care, not to come near this Apartment, for he hates the ſight of Women.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That's falſe, to my knowledge—for he ſaid the ſofteſt things to me, that Love cou'd form; (aſide.) ſay, you ſo, Brother? an Unpoliſhed Brute, I hope, he is not to continue long here?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Only, for two or three Days—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, my heart—ſo ſhort a ſtay. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Ho, here he comes, retire Siſter.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I muſt ſee him again—tho' you prevent me now; if I don't break through this Conſtraint, ſay, Woman wants contrivance.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Why then, this prov'd, a confounded miſtake, Sir, but were it poſſible you cou'd not know the Houſe again?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How cou'd I, when I was convey'd the back way into an Apartment, where I never was before; the cuningeſt Man alive, might have been deceived, as well as I—but the gift of Impudence is a wonderful gift; ha! Sir VVilliam—I did not ſee thee.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: I believe not, Love and Variety, clouds thy ſight, but what is the Diſappointment, you ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am an unlucky Dog, that's all—I fell into the Company of both my Miſtreſſes, at once.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: This 'tis, to have more Intreagues, than one can manage, ha, ha, ha; and how did you behave your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith en'cavalierement—I ſtuck cloſe to the Name of Conſtant, and my Incognita—for I like her beſt.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Till he ſees ſome body he likes better. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
And Swore, I never ſaw t'other, in my life, nor never heard of the Name of, Revell—but was as downright
a Country Gentleman, and made Love as gravely, as ever a Squire of'em all.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: And did the Impoſition paſs?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not without Scruple—but I'll undertake to make my ſelf two diſtinct perſons, as clear as the Sun at Noon-Day, if thou'lt aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: How? for the Frolicks ſake, I care not I if do—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then, as I have occaſion, you ſhall receive Inſtructions, I want a Meſſenger in my Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: That I can procure you—but to what purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You ſhall know in time—I ſhall want thy perſonal appearance too.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: You ſhall want nothing, in my power—but prithy, do you like either of 'em well enough to Marry?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In my Conſcience I think I cou'd be content with the Nooſe, if my Incognita's Family be anſwerable to her beauty—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nay, if he grows honourably in Love, I may hope for ſome reſt at laſt. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why will ye not quit the other then?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: T'other is Related, and a Friend—if I deceive her not, ſhe'l maliciouſly ſpoil my intreague; beſides, 'tis a pritty Amuſement, and the deſign ſo Novel, that I muſt purſue it for the pleaſure of Invention, and I think it poſſible to perſorm; we have ſeen two People ſo very like, that when abſent they cou'd not be diſtinguiſh'd from one another.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: But if the Faces wore Reſemblance, the Voice Shape diſcover'd it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But a good Aſſurance ſolves all that.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Why, Sir, if the worſt come to the worſt—that they will both have you—why en'e marry them both, keep one for your ſelf, and t'other to entertain your Friends—or, if you pleaſe, Sir,—to do you a Service, I don't care if I take one of 'em off your hands,

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Then you'l venture to rely upon your Maſter's choice, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, ſooner than ever a Man in England; my Maſter, has taſted ſo many of thoſe Diſhes—that I dare muſt to his Palate.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You are witty, Raſcal, ha! Who have we here, thy Mimick.

div.stage: Enter Wou'dbe, dreſt like Sir William, and Ned. Freelove.

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: Well, I have ſurprized ſome Ladies, ſtrangely, that ſtop'd their Coach, and call'd out Sir VVilliam, Sir VVilliam; and when I turn'd back, and they diſcover'd their Miſtake, they bluſh'd intollerably, ha, ha, ha. (aſide to Ned.)

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Nay, your Dreſs is exactly the ſame with his; the miſtake was very eaſy.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Mr. VVou'dbe, your Servant.

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: Surprizing! another Suit!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what a Conſternation you have put him in?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: What's the matter with you, Sir? This minute you look'd as Gay, and Pleaſant, as the Month of June, and now it is December at leaſt—he has diſcover'd you, Brother.

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: Moſt beatifically expreſt, and worthy of Quotation. (Takes out a Pocket-book, and writes.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I preſume, Sir, you are examining, what Aſſignations fall out this hour, that you may not diſappoint the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: No, Sir, I am taking Cognizance of the Gentleman's Wit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I hope, you are not one of thoſe Spungy-Brain'd Poets, that ſuck ſomething from all Companies to ſqueeze into a Comedy, at Acting of which, the Pit and Boxes may laugh at their own Jeſts.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Where each may claim his ſhare of Wit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And by my conſent, ſhou'd claim a ſhare of the Profits too, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: This is a Gentleman of an intellectual Sublimity—No, Sir, I contemn the Terrene extraction of thoſe poor Animals, whoſe Barren-Intellects thruſts ſuch ſpurious Brats abroad; when I write, it ſhall be all my own, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Wou'dbe can never want aſſiſtance of that kind.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: What ſhall I do with theſe Cloths! I wou'd not give a Farthing for'em, now he has left 'em off—and that's ten times the prittier Suit in my opinion—Well, he is the moſt genteel Fellow in Europe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, the Incognita's Maid, Sir, has brought you this Letter, and ſtays for an Anſwer. [Gives him a Letter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha! (Reads— My Conſin has a ſtrange opinion of you, and nothing but your Perſonal appearance immediately can prevent my giving credit to her Story; make haſt, if you expect any farther favours from your Incognita—any farther favours! Yes, I do expect farther favours, or I'd never take half this pains—Let me ſee (pauſes.)

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: I wiſh'd I cou'd ſell this Coat—I ſhall never indure the ſight of it, that's certain. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hark ye, Sirrah, do you tell the Maid, I'll not fail the Summons—and do you hear, follow her at a diſtance, till you ſee her Hous'd; if he goes to Belizas, do you ask to ſpeak with Beliza's Couſin, and tell her you left me in the Street talking to ſome body, but that ſhe might not think me long, I ſent you before; beſure you make no blunders, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir, Lying is become my Vocation; but, Sir, what Name, Sir!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Conſtant, you forgetful Blockead.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ha, I have it, the Country Gentleman, Sir—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, ay, away. (aſide to Robin.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What, another Biliet Doux?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis from my unknown—now for thy Aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: What contrivance ſhall I have for ſuch a Dreſs—my Rogue of a Tayler will not truſt, that's certain. Let me think—that won't do—nor that—ho, I have it— [Takes out his Book and writes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This Meſſenger muſt be had immediately, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I'll procure you one inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then I'm Maſter of my Art.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Sir William, I recommend that to your peruſal (Gives him the Tablets.) If this Project takes not, I'm undone— (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What's this (Reads.) We whoſe Names are here Subſcrib'd, do promiſe to make our Perſonal Appearance in the Side-Box, the third Day of a new Play, either Tragedy, Comedy, Farce, or Opera, that ſhall be written by Timothy Wou'dbe, Eſq and Play'd at one of the Houſes or both, as the Players can agree about that, on forfeit of a Guinea, which we have depoſited in the hands of the Author.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, a pritty contrivance for another Suit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is new, indeed, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I love to encourage Ingenuity, he has flung away many a Guinea after me, now I'll give him one—pray, Enter me down Mr. Wou'dbe.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Let me intreat your own hand, for the Incouragement of others. (Sir William writes.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'll not be out at a Frolick, there's mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: There, Brother, enter your Name too— (Gives Ned a Guinea)

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha, ha, with all my heart, there is Belvil, Loveill, and Freewit—you may depend on, Mr. Wou'dbe.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: I'll wait on 'em incontinently.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But, when is this Play to be writ, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: That I muſt conſider on, Sir; too many things at once deſtroy the Thought, and dull the Fancy.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe it ſhou'd not live till the third Day, the Town is very Capricious.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: I know it, Sir, for that reaſon, I took this method; when their Gold is at ſtake, they'l bring in their Bodies, to ſave their Bail—egad, I ſhan't have Money enough—Let me ſee—I'll ſell theſe Cloths, to make it up—Gentlemen, I'm your moſt Oblig'd—

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he is upon the wing, with his Subſcription, I'll follow, and ſee if he goes to their Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Now, for thy buſineſs, Bellair, where ſhall I find you half an hour hence?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Here, for I muſt now dreſs me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, thus far I'm right—now for half an hours Reſpit from the fateague of buſineſs—egad, I wiſh the Pritty Creature, I ſaw in the Morning, wou'd fall in my way—who the duce is ſhe, I wonder—no matter who, ſhe's handſome—and that's knowledge enough, to Recommend her—Ha! here ſhe comes, by Jove.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Here he is! a charming handſom Fellow—what Excuſe ſhall I make?—ha—I thought Sir William had been here—Sir, I beg your pardon—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He's juſt gon out, Madam, he's a happy Man, to have ſo much Beauty in queſt of him.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Beauty's an Epithet your Sex never fail to make uſe of to raiſe our Vanity, when preſent, but the Object once remov'd, you ſoon recal your Praiſes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sometimes, Madam, good Manners produce Adulation; but here Flattery dares not ſhow her Face, your Charms are ſo conſpicuous, they need no Art to inform your Knowledge, nor I no Cunning to inſlave my ſelf; I am Chain'd already, your Eyes at firſt ſight reduc'd me, and the ſhort moments which we paſs'd this day together, made ſuch an Impreſſion on my Heart, that I have thought of nothing ſince but how to ſee you again.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Oh! How his Words run thro' my Soul—alaſs, Sir, to what purpoſe ſhou'd you ſee me, I am Married.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Wretchedly Married.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Better and better—wretchedly Married, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Wretchedly—to an old peviſh diſponding Wretch.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As I cou'd wiſh—her diſlike of her Husband is my firſt ſtep to Poſſeſſion— (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Forc'd by my Friends to Wed him, by which all my happineſs in this World is loſt.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Baniſh that thought my charming Creature—'tis a falſe one; there are Joys, ineſtimable Joys in Store, give me but leave, and I'll inform you where they may be reap'd. (taking her Hand.)

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Not by me without a Crime.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Crime be on their Heads that forc'd your Marriage, Nature ne'er deſign'd theſe Charms ſhou'd wither in the Arms of Age, and deſtin'd only to a Clod—beſides your not conſenting to the Match, makes it invalid, and of no force to hold you—take pity, then, both of yourſelf and me, I languiſh, ſigh, diſpair—nay, e'en die for you.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Help me, Heaven, I have no Power to Speak—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! do not ſtrugle ſo, nor daſh my riſing Hopes, leave me not, except you wiſh my Death, which I reſolve the moment you depart—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Forbid that Thought, I cannot ſee you die—yet muſt not yield; let me go for Virtues ſake—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Love forbids it—Oh! I ſhall faint with Extacy of Pleaſure—no Jeſſemin nor Roſe has half the ſweets that dwell upon theſe Lips, 'tis Eſſence from the Throne of Jove—this Neck, this Breaſt—Oh! every part about thee is Celeſtial, Loadſtone like, thy Breath attracts and draws my Lips to thine. (kiſſing her.)

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Oh! the difference between his Kiſſes, and my Husband's, what ſhall I do.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do! Conſent to bleſs the Man that loves you.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: But how long will he do ſo?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's ever the Women's Queſtion—ask not that; can I prove falſe to ſo much Beauty, oh, no, faithful as the Needle to its Pole, or Turtle to his Mate, ſecret as a Prieſt—and loving as the Vine—give me Poſſeſſion once, and bind the trueſt of his Sex for ever— (pulling her.)

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Ah, (ſhreecks.) my Husband's Voice.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: (within) Ah, Thieves, Thieves.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Curſe of all ill Luck—Juſt in the critical Minute when ſhe was yielding—'Death, what ſhall I do, Madam, can, can, can, can, you put me no where?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Impoſſible, he'll ſearch all the Houſe—now the Duce take me for Shreeking— (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then there's no way—but to cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Now help me, dear, dear Invention. (pauſes.)

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Baſilicon, why where's my Surgeon there—I ſhall be Murder'd, here's Thieves got into my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: A lucky hint, improve it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Improve what?

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: What's here, a Man, a Thief, a Thief, fall on, fall on.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I ſhall be apprehended for a Rogue, here—make your Mermidons; be civil, Sir, or I ſhall whip you thro' the Guts, by Hercules. (Lays his Hand on his Sword.)

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Baſilicon, keep near me Baſilicon—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Oh! Hold, hold, Sir Paul, What do you do? Abuſe a Gentleman that came to ſave your Life.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What the Devil does ſhe mean now—ſome turn to bring me off, if I can but hit her right.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Tell him you ſaw the Houſe beſet with Rogues, tell him, tell him, any thing. (aſide to Bell.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Humph, ha, Oh, witty Rogue—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Ha, how's that?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I came to do you Service.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: As how, pray, ſweet, Sir? To lye with my Wife, ha!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, Sir, coming by your Houſe I ſaw four Men, and heard 'em ſay, that's the Door, dog him to ſome Convenient place, and then ſecure him.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Secure me, for what, Sir? I owe no body nothing, I have no employment in the State, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Riches is much talk'd on, Sir, and People imagine you have got that which we call the Philoſopher's Stone; I believe they deſign to Rob and Murder you, I heard 'em mutter ſomething of Ripping you up, and Defecting you.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Oh! Bloody Villians.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Excellent Fellow— (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They talk'd as if you ſwallow'd the Stone every Morning, and kept it in your Body for greater ſecurity all Day.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Monſtrous!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I find their deſign is to ſearch for that Stone, which, if they get it, will make them as Rich as Aldermen ever after.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Barbarous—Sir, if you'l believe me, I don't know what they mean by the Philoſopher's Stone, as I hope for long Life—I have no Stone worth a Groat, except the Stone of this Ring.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, I know nothing of that, Sir, I thought my ſelf bound in Honour, tho' unknown to you, to give you notice of your Danger.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Sir, I heartily thank you—My Coach-man, indeed, told me there was four Men behind my Coach laſt Night, which made me not go abroad to day; theſe muſt be the Rogues.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: It paſſes as I wou'd have it—but I wiſh he had been at the bottom of the Sea, when he interrupted us, for that Charming Fellow has got my Heart, I ſind that. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pox take him, for his unſeaſonable Intruſion. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: I thought I heard you Screek out, Wife.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: I wiſh I had been Dumb when I did—yes, my Dear, with deſign to raiſe the Houſe, to purſue, and take the Rogues, this Gentleman told me of, at leaſt diſperſe 'em, that my Love might be in no danger.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Oh, was that it, very well—come you, and I, will retire to my Cloſet, and return thanks for this Deliverance, Baſilicon; come you along with us, Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: I never had leſs Religion about me in my Life.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If thou had'ſt ſtay'd but one quarter of an hour longer, Old Noll, thou ſhou'dſt have had ſomething to have thank'd me for.

sp.speaker: Servant,
sp.p: Sir William ſends to tell you, that he, and the Gentleman you want, ſtays for you at the Coffee-houſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I come— (Exit Servant.) was there ever ſuch a promiſing Project croſt; I muſt have her—and I find ſhe muſt have me too—

l.hi: What various hazards do we Rovers run,
To purchaſe what we ſlight, as ſoon as won;
And Women know it too, yet long to be undone.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: HEre ſhe went in!—let me ſee—I am to ſay—what am I to ſay?—pox on't, my Maſter gives me ſo many different Leſſons, one knocks 'tother out of my Head—he is doing—doing, no, no, he did not bid me ſay he was doing—he was ſtopt in the Street—ay, ay, that's right, and his Name—Zads bud, I have forgot his Name now—but here's the Maid, and ſo 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Ha! Robin! is your Maſter come?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: He's coming, Child—a Lawyer, I believe, for he had a ſwinging ſtroke with his Tongue, ſtopt him in the Street, about his Law Suit, I ſuppoſe, ſo he ſent me Expreſs, fraught with his eager Wiſhes, to beg thy Lady's patience for two Minuets only, and then he'l throw himſelf at her Feet—egad, I think I have made as noble a Speech as ever a Courtier of 'em all. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Why don't you come in, and deliver your Meſſage, then?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Now I have ſeen thee, I dare not.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Why, what do you fear?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thoſe pinking Ogles of thine—But now I think on't, if my Maſter and your Lady Cupple, thoul't fall to me of Courſe.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: To you—I believe not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: But I believe yes—are not we perquiſites made for one another?—our Station's the ſame—our Imployment alike—you Dreſs your Lady—ſo do I my Maſter—you receive, and deliver Meſſages, ſo do I—and lying is the common Vocation of us both.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You are very familier in your Courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: 'Tis my way—but I know Truth is an out-of-faſhon'd Courtſhip, which your Sex is not us'd too. Ha! my Maſter. (Enter Bellair dreſt for Revel.) Sir, I did your Meſſage.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Meſſage, Fellow, what Meſſage? This Dog will ſpoil all by his blunders; he do's not ſee that I'm Revel now; (aſide.) do you know who you ſpeak too?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: By my troth, I don't know—and yet methinks I ſhou'd know too.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: 'Tis very ſtrange if he ſhou'd not know his Maſter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Why, Sir, pray are not you my Maſter, co, co, co.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Raſcal. (Strikes him a box on the Ear.)

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Egad, I'm in the wrong, but where I can't tell—his Fingers are grown plaguy Flippant of late.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is Beliza within, my Dear, doſt know?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I believe ſhe is, Sir—I'll let her know you'd ſpeak with her, if you pleaſe to ſignify what Name you'l wear at preſent—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Name! Why, my own Name, Child, Revel; what Name ſhou'd I wear? Thou art pleaſant, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: There was my miſtake, now. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Here ſhe comes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So Darts the Sun, thro' all the thick wrought Clouds, to Chear the labouring Swain. (Catching her in his Arms.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p:
Hold, Sir! Who are you, pray? The Colonel, or the Country Gentleman—the Grave, Serious, formal Lover,
or the Gay Rakiſh Soldier?—let me know, I beſeech you, that I may ſquare my Converſation to yours.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha▪ ha, ha, Why theſe Interrogatories? Madam, do you walk in your Sleep?—now I fancy you are in a Dream; ay, it is ſo, faith—and I cannot reſiſt the Opportunity for Gloves. (Kiſſes her.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Away, thou exquiſite Diſſembler—How can you look me in the Face.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Becauſe I don't know a Face in Europe that pleaſes me half ſo well—but prithy, why this Air of indifference, or rather, reſentment? Look ye, Madam, if you affect this Quarrel by the way of Poignant Sauce—you have no need of thoſe little recourſes of your Sex—Revel Loves as much as ever, and dare promiſe—

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: More than you perform.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Accuſe me not before you try me—but why theſe Croſs Purpoſes—ha, my Incognita! now Bellair, play thy part (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Here's one will inform you.—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Conſtant, are you come?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Conſtant! yes, faith, Madam, I'm as conſtant as any Man—this Lady can witneſs for me.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Not in the Court of Conſcience, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then you have no Conſcience at all.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: If my Maſter took up lying by the Week, what a Confounded Intereſt 'twou'd come to in a Year. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Do you know why I ſent for you ſo ſoon, Mr. Conſtant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, Madam—nor that you-ſent for me at all.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: You miſtake, Couſin, this is Colonel Revel, ha, ha▪

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Colonel fiddle, is it not?—ſure I know Mr Conſtant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Conſtant! Who is he, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Who's he? Why, are not you he?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not that I know off.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Ha, ha, you ſhall be Revel, Sir, till Conſtant comes, if my Couſin will give you leave—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I'm ſurpriz'd at his Impudence—pray, were not you here two Hours ago, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not that I remember—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Impoſſible—did not you ſave me from drowning, Yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Twas in my ſleep, then—for waking I am ſure I did not.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Diſtraction—Nor is not your Name Conſtant? And Oxfordſhire.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Quite wrong—this is a pretty Chriſtmas Game Lady—but, pray let me have ſome Commands, as well as all Queſtions.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Nor you don't know this Footman?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Agen—No, Madam, never scaw him in my Life.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Oh Lord, who am I now—ſor he has renounc'd me heartily. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: What ſay you, Friend, don't you know this Gentleman neither?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: No more than I do the great Mogul; Madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Who do you belong to—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Belong to, Madam! why, why, why, a pox of his 'tother Name, now I can't think on't, if I were to be hang'd. (aſide.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ay, who do you belong to, I ſay, again?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Why, I belong to my Maſter, Madam.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: And what is that Maſter's Name, pray?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Name, Madam—his Name is—ad, now I think on't, I won't tell his Name—why, ſure I'm too big to be Catechiz'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This Dog will betray me. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You challeng'd this for your Maſter, juſt now.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What if I did, Miſtreſs, what then? He is not, it ſeems, without his being double, as you pretend—the Devil ſhou'd have doubled me too.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: What buſineſs have you here?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Buſineſs! why I brought a Meſſage from my Maſter to one of you—and ſo good by—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Hold, ſtay, Sir—pray, what was that Meſſage?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Why, that my Maſter wou'd be here, preſently—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, I ſuppoſe, this is Mr. Conſtant's Man, that you miſtake me for—ah, pox of his Memory. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You have hit it, Sir—Mr. Conſtant is my Maſter, now his Name's out—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I'm aſtoniſh'd! Couſin, did you ever hear the like?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Yes, the very ſame—but I traduc'd Mr. Conſtant then, you know—What ſay you, Revel, did I?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hey, Ladies! do you deſign to bait me, if ſo, give me fair play, at leaſt—harkye, draw off your Couſin, and confeſs your Plot—or egad I'll humour her Frenzy, take the Name of Conſtant, and make Love to her before your Face.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Withal my heart, 'tis not the firſt time—and I have no further Services for you, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: So, he's in a fair way to looſe 'em both (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: I Arreſt you, Sir, in an Action of High Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Treaſon, Sir! Sure you miſtake the Man.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Ha! how's this?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: Your Name's Revel, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Name is Revel, Sir, but guilty of no ſuch Crime.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Here's a turn now—I muſt ſecond him. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: That muſt be prov'd, 'tis no buſineſs of mine, I am only to Execute my Orders.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I am concern'd for him, methinks—won't you take Bail, Sir?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: In theſe caſes no Bail is admitted, Madam.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: My Mind miſgives me, this is a Trick.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I can't ſtay—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, pray Enter my Action too, for a Box of the Ear he gave me juſt now—this is ſome comfort, however, I ſhall ſee him hang'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, I can eaſily prove my Innocence—if I ſtand fair in this Lady's Opinion, I cannot fear the World. (to Beliza.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: I wiſh you a good Deliverance, Colonel—I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I'll ſee him lodg'd, I'm reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Nor I—to what end can a Man affect theſe Diſguiſes?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Out of Gallantry, Couſin—I ſhall hardly be convinc'd without I ſaw them both together—I pitty the Colonel's Unhappy Diſgrace; but, believe me, now he is Arreſted, Conſtant is no more, his Man following him plainly ſhew'd the Cheat.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Nay, I confeſs they are extreamly alike, but obſerving very narrowly, I think their Features are not exactly the ſame.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You are of my mind, Madam—for methinks, he is half an Inch taller than Mr. Conſtant.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And ſomething about his Face, I don't know what—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I fancy his Noſe is ſomething longer.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Thou haſt hit it; it is his Noſe, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Beliza.
sp.p: You are both mad I'm ſure—ha, ha, ha,—bleſs me! Pray, Heaven it ben't the Devil that thus deludes us.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am come, Madam, according to your Commands—but if my Reception now prove like the laſt, the pleaſure of ſeeing you, will much abate—I am firſt at the Rendezvous, I perceive.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Now, Couſin, you are convinc'd, I hope.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: You are, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Now, Madam, I can tell you the very difference, his Eyes are a little-little larger.

sp.speaker: Cam.
