sp.p: Nay, I think they are a great deal larger.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why do you Survey me ſo, Madam? is it poſſible, that you can be deceiv'd too—Where is this Colonel to be found? Will he not come?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: He is juſt gone.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: He has Diſingag'd himſelf, Sir, to leave you room, to Act your part.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why did not you keep him, I ſent my Man before me, to let you know, I would inſtantly be here.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: How could we, when the Queen's Authority favour'd his Retreat.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How ſay you, Madam? has the Queen ſent for him.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: How cunningly you Diſſemble—but that's not new, Diſſimulation, ſeems your natural gift.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Still theſe Reproaches, will nothing, that I ſay convince you?—Why did you conſent to let him go?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Why, do you really think this is ſtill the ſame? (to Beliza.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: I do really—the Trap was laid with too much Policy to be prevented, knowing the Meſſenger I never ſuſpected the truth of the Action—but I may change to Counter Plot you yet

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, ſhe is gone to the Priſon—but ſhe'l return as unſatisfied as ſhe went (aſide.) Why do you take pleaſure to inſult the Man, your Beauty has inſlav'd? If my Viſits be offenſive—tho' I die without you—I prefer your Peace ſo much above my own, I'll never diſturb you with my Preſence more.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: He looks, methinks, with ſuch an honeſt Face, it can be only Conſtant; (aſide.) you muſt own, I have reaſon to ſuſpect you—but you have a powerful Advocate within, which Pleads in your excuſe, and fain wou'd Juſtifie you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: At laſt, I am ſatisfied—the Spark is Cag'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Did you follow him?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Do you doubt it?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Whom, ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, are you there?—you'l be hang'd in Effigie to morrow—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How, Sauſe-box!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, he did Box me, but I ſhall have a ſwinging Revenge.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Revenge, for what?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Why, Sir, your likeneſs—that here has been ſuch a ſputter about—is taken up for Treaſon, Murder, Robbery, and the Devil and all—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, misfortune! to be like ſuch a Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Ay, ſo it is indeed, Sir—I thought he wou'd have been pull'd to pieces in the Street—there were Girls of Fourteen,
and Women of Fourſcore, with Actions of Raviſhment againſt him—and Tavern, and Eating-houſe Bills in abundance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Rogue has improv'd the hint admirably (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: 'Tis an illbred Scroundrel, he is very like you, Sir, that's the truth on't,) he gave me the damndeſt Box on the Ear, only becauſe I miſtook him for you—he has a ſwinging Fiſt, Sir, that was all the Diſtinction I cou'd make between you—but I ſhall ſee him truſs'd up for it, that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I am extreamly pleas'd to find they are two different Perſons—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Conſtant! I can't believe my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why, what ſurpriſes thee?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I met thy very Likeneſs in Cuſtody of a Meſſenger, and ſtop'd 'em to examin the reaſon—the Spark ſnapt me up ſhort, and told me 'twas none of my buſineſs, bad 'em paſs on—I admir'd at the meaning, for I cou'd have ſworn it had been thee—ha! that is Beliza's Lodgings, certainly. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Were he Dreſt like me too?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, that was the only Diſtinction I found about him—I wiſh Beliza ben't the other Woman—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now, Madam—are you ſtill in ſuſpence?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I'm convinc'd, and over-joy'd, to find you what I wiſh you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: If my Suſpicions be true, I have a pritty kind of an Employment here—ſerving my Rival againſt my ſelf, (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Madam, your Father wants you—he talks of having you Married to Night—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: How's that, egad, my Maſter will be ſobb'd at laſt, I fear. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Oh, Unfortunate—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: If it be ſo, 'tis ſome pleaſure at leaſt to know the Man. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
What do I hear? Oh, Madam, if ever pity touch'd your Soul, exert it now—think where you are going, think
too, who you leave—give me ſome aſſurance to ſupport my hope, that you will diſobey your Father—or, I am miſerable.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Believe me, my ſurprize is as great as yours, I promiſe to uſe my utmoſt Arguments againſt it; if I fail, you then ſhall know my Father, and uſe your own Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's all I ask—unexpected turn of ill Fortune▪ this News has chang'd the very Countenance.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, one wou'd ſwear thou wer't really in Love.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And not be forſworn, Sir William; for, faith, I do love her heartily, and am ready to Capitulate for better for worſe, as ſoon as ſhe pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear that—one thing, pray, tell me, without reſerve—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Moſt willingly—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What deſign have you upon the other; for you can't marry 'em both?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Humph—faith, no deſign at all, if I cou'd come off handſomely; tho' ſhe's very pritty, but too well acquainted with my Incognita, to have any Intrigue with.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Does ſhe love you Bellair?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not that ever I cou'd diſcover, to ſay the Truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: One thing more—is not her Name Beliza!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha! does he know her—I'm afraid my Plot's ſpoil'd again. (aſide.) Nay, Sir William, don't force me to tell Names, eſpecially after the Stratagem I have made uſe of.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I am convinc'd 'tis the ſame; had I apprehended it ſooner, Friend, you had not carried your deſign thus far.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, I have made my Rival, my Confident; I find I am a lucky Fellow, now, may he, out of pure Revenge diſcover me (aſide.) If I have committed any fault; Sir William, 'twas a fault of Ignorance; could I devine the Lady was your Acquaintance—ſo that I am aſſur'd your Friendſhip muſt forgive me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What Friendſhip muſt forgive, Love denies—as I imagin'd, here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Sir William, whatever ſatisfaction you demand I'm ready to return—this favour let me obtain, as you are a Gentleman betray me not, to my fair Unknown—this is the moſt unfortunate thing.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Quite undone again.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: I am confounded! I know not whether there be two or not—the Meſſenger affirms that Revell is in his Cuſtody, but his Orders run ſo ſtrickt, that none muſt be admitted to ſee him—ha, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pray, what was the Subject of your Ladyſhip's Comtemplation—Colonel Revell.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: He has found it then at laſt—why, do you know Colonel Revell, Sir William?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You do, I find—perſidious Woman—have I diſcovered thy falſhood—all thy turnings and windings of indifference, had their ſource from hence.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: The readieſt way to ſtop his Tongue, is to let looſe mine. (aſide.) Do, do, exalt your Voice, and raiſe your Paſſion hgher—but know! your jealous Rage ſhall extort no Submiſſion from me, tho' I cou'd clear my innocence with eaſe—but the Man that dares ſuſpect my conduct—and ſtart a Quarrel Husband-like, er'e I have confirmed his Title, I ſcorn to diſabuſe—ſo leave him to what method he thinks beſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Oh, guilt! What an Aſſurance doſt thou give, Oh, Hell, Hell.

l.hi: What Fate than this cou'd more injurions prove,
Deceiv'd by Friendſhip, and deſtroy'd by Love

head.hi: Scene Changes to Sir William's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You Act your part very well, Sir, but there was one thing Superſluous, in that of Revell.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What was that prithy?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: The Box o'th' Ear, Sir; 'twas very uncomfortable.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: On, there's a Cordial for thee. (Gives him Money) 'twas only to teach you a good Decorum.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, your humble Servant, I am ready to be taught, Sir, when ever you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But how are you ſure my Father knows I am in Town.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sure on't, Sir! why I ſaw him, and told him you came but Two hours ago—and that, you'd wait upon him as ſoon as you had refreſh'd your ſelf with clean Linning—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Z'death, and why did you ſo Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Becauſe, Sir, that was the firſt excuſe that came at my Tongues end—and you know there is no humming and hawing with my Old Maſter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am in a bleſſed Condition,—in Love, with I know not who, to be found I know not where—undoubtedly out of Favour with my Father, if I refuſe his Choice, as I moſt certainly ſhall—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir, ben't over certain—may be ſhe's as handſome as t'other—and you may like her as well.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And, in all probability, in danger of a Duel with my Friend—to rectify all theſe matters, require a Machivilian Brain—go you wait at t'other Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.—Now has he ſo many Women upon his Hands, he knows not what to do with 'em—the firſt time I ever ſaw him puzzled in theſe matters—

div.stage: Lady Cautious paſſing over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Charmer! the ſight of thee diſpels my malancholy, and revives the Joy within my Breaſt, which firſt thoſe Eyes inſpired—

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why, were you Malancholy, Sir? impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How ſhou'd I be otherwiſe in the abſence of my Love▪

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Abundance of Love, but not a grain of Conſtancy I Fear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As conſtant as the Sun, my faireſt—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What, like him, Court all you meet, and quit as ſoon as taſted—Nature never deſign'd my Sex to feed your Luxery—but for Health, Content and Neceſſaries.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Right, why then can you deny the Man that endeavours to engroſs thoſe Neceſſaries you ſpeak of.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Where they are Lawful—but upon ſecond thoughts, I find I have ſcruples—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Vapors, Vapors, all—Lawful! Why the Mechanical notion I have of the World, is a rich Banquet, ſet off with all the choiceſt things of the Creation—where Man's the gueſt—and wou'd it not be the height of ill Manners to ſnatch a Diſh, and run away with it, when, perhaps, twenty more had a mind to the ſame Meat—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: And wou'd it not be the extremity of Folly to taſt of every Diſh—when your curioſity may bring a Surfci.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then there's Phyſicians enough in Town to cure me—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Or kill you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: With all my Heart—becauſe a Houſe may fall on my Head—muſt I therefore lie in the Field—but what have we to do with Philoſophy?

l.hi: For ſofter Pleaſures was your Sex deſign'd,
Heaven form'd, and ſent 'em to delight Mankind.
No Rule or Cuſtom, did we firſt obey,
But freely lov'd where Nature led the way.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Bleſs me! you'l ſmother me—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let us not in cold Diſputing waſt the time, leaſt Fortune, angry at our dull delay, ſend another interruption—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Well, you was born to ruin me—but do not, pray, do not—uſe your force—for well I find my weakneſs— (in a yielding Tone.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A good hint—ſure fortune will not Jilt me agian—but hold, I'll ſecure the Door— (ſhuts the Door.) now ſhow me a Man poſſeſt of half an hour's happineſs above me. (takes hold of her.)

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Undone for ever—there's ſome body at the Doo • if I'm diſcover'd—Ruin attends me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Another malicious Devil has croſt me again— 〈◊〉 why, why—which way ſhall I get out? Is there 〈◊〉 Stairs, nor Trap Door—I, I, I, I'll Jump out of the Win •••…

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: By no means—what will come of me—here, here, get into that Cloſet. (Knocks again.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, ay, any where—oh, Succeſs, Succeſs, thou haſt forſaken me
sp.stage: (ſhe ſhuts the Door, then opens tother.)

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Who knocks with that Authority? Brother, is it you! what ſhall I ſay? (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What buſineſs have you here—Confuſion, how ſhall I contain my ſelf? (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: If he has diſcover'd me, I'm a dead Woman (aſide.) why do you look ſo angry, Brother—Is it a Crime to be in your Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, I forbad you—and what was the Door ſhut for, ha?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: I ſhall be found out, there's no avoiding it—becauſe I was afraid the ſtranger which you ſay hates Women ſhou'd ſurprize me—I came hither to be private, and to avoid the Impertinency of Sir Paul—I tremble every Joint. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, ſhe did come to avoid Sir Paul, that's plain enough—Oh, Nature, Nature, why did'ſt thou make a Woman?—I'm ſure I heard his Voice—far off he cannot be—that Cloſet muſt conceal him—I'm glad to find you was ſo Circumſpect, Siſter—I am out of Humour—you'l forgive me—how ſhall I get rid of her. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Better than I expected— (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pray, oblige me with Pen, Ink, and Paper, I have loſt the Key of my Scrutore, and can't come at mine—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: With all my heart, Brother—a fortunate eſcape (exit.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Let me conſider—ſhall I ſacrifice his Blood to my injur'd honour—no, I owe this Life to him which now I beat—and a ſolemn League of Friendſhip joyn'd our Souls—I Lodg'd him here—and ſhall I break the Laws of Hoſpitality?—no—firſt, let me know how far my Honour is concern'd—if my Siſter has betray'd her Virtue—and I prove it—my juſt Reſentment then ſhall fall on both—'tis reſolv'd— (puts out the Candle, goes to the Cloſet and knocks. Sir, Sir— (Bellair opens the Door, and comes out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Are they gone, my Life, my Love—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: My Life, my Love! Damnation (aſide.) they are gone, huſh, make no noiſe for your Life, I expect my Husband every Minute, therefore if you Love me retire inſtantly—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Love thee; do I live? But, Oh, I fear theſe curſt malicious Planets ne're will Crown my wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: By that I find he has not enjoy'd her—now to know how far ſhe's inclin'd.— (goes into the Cloſet, and ſhuts the Door after him.

div.stage: Enter Lady Cautious with Pen, Ink and Paper.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Here's Pen and Ink, Brother—ha, in the dark, Brother—Brother—ha! gonc—lucky opportunity—let me 'ſcape now, and I'll never run the danger more— (goes to the Cloſet.) you may come out, the Coaſt is clear

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Then I'm happy—now let's us loſe no time—but improve the precious Moments—conduct me to ſome more private place, there let me breath my Soul into your Boſom, and pay the hazards which we have both run—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: This is no time, except you wiſh my Ruin—my Brother is alarm'd, and may return this Minute, and Sacrifice me to his Jealouſe Fears—have you no regard for my ſafety—yet will you loiter to undo me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Deſtruction ſeize thee, (aſide.) I will go, but firſt tell me when, and where, I ſhall be bleſt again.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Preſs me not to further folly—I own the tender Sentiments of my Heart—and fear I love you—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Excellent Confeſſion.— (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But my fears grow ſtrong, and repreſent Vice in hideous Forms—twice this day Surprize perſerv'd my Virtue.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Twice! Oh, Traytereſs. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: And now by all the Virtuous Stars, I'll never ſee you more. (Flings from him, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
I'm glad to hear that—but did not ſhe know me? So took her Opportunity to ſtart from my Vengeance? It may be ſo, and this be all a Lye—it muſt be ſo—and now I cou'd rip that Boſome where her Heart, her hot Luſtful
Heart reſides—yes, if thou be'ſt Guilty—theſe Hands ſhall ſtrait let out thy tainted Blood, to waſh the Stains thou haſt thrown upon our Family.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Mercy on me, what a noiſe is here in this Houſe—Zadsbud, it were a Bleſſing to be Deaf—what did I ſay—Heaven forgive me—if I ſhou'd be ſtruck Deaf now, what a lamentable thing 'twou'd be—humph—ha—in my Conſcience, my Ears Sings, I have a ſtrange huming in my Head—pray, Heaven, I grow not Deaf in earneſt—Well, my Wife has ſo many Relations—that Lodge here, and Viſit her together—I ſhall certainly be undone—it coſts me, at leaſt, Five Pound a Week in Coffee—Tea—Chocolate—and Ratefia—Mercy upon me—if I ſhou'd come to want now in my old Age—I may thank Marriage for it—if I ſhou'd come to be maintain'd by the Pariſh now—Oh, ſad—Oh, ſad—or ſhou'd live to be Blind—and led with a Dog and a Bell—what ſhall I do, if I come to that, and who knows but I may—Let me ſee, let me ſee, I'll try how I can walk in the Dark. (puts out the Candle.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Devil take theſe Diſappointments, I ſay—I have peep'd into every room I cou'd find open, but no ſight of her—well, if my Incognita—falls to my Lot at laſt, 'twill be ſome amends—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: What a wretched condition it is to be depriv'd of Sight—the very Apprehenſion puts me in a ſwet all over—ah, ah, within there, Lights, Lights.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I can't imagine into what part of the Houſe I'm got. (runs againſt Sir Paul.)

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: What's that? Thieves, Thieves.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pox take this old Cuff, how came I to ſtumble on him.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Baſilicon, why Baſilicon, I ſay, Murder, Murder.

div.stage: Enter Servants with Lights, and Baſilicon.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, I'm glad to ſee you withal my Heart—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p:
That's a lye, I believe—but what's your buſineſs here now, Sir? Anſwer me that—do you come to
bring me another Information of Rogues, ha! I know you again—either you come, Sirrah, to make me a Cuckold—or to Rob my Houſe—but I'll have you laid by the Heels—I will ſo—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very fine, faith—my next ſtep will be to Tyburn.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Bind his Hands, there—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Keep off Scoundrils—without you'l have your Guts full of Oylet-holes.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Oh, Baſilicon, ſee, ſee, am I not wounded? Keep cloſe to me.

sp.speaker: Baſ.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter here—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, Sir William, you come opportunely, to ſave me from theſe Raſcals.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Sir Paul, why theſe Diſorders? Of what are you Apprehenſive—this Gentleman is a Friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: But how came he here, Sir, in the Dark—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I miſtook this for Sir VVilliam's Apartment—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Oh, Hippocriſy—but e're you and I have done, you'l own 'twas upon another Score (aſide.) it muſt be ſo, Sir Paul, I lent my Lodgings to this Gentleman for two or three Days—curſe of my ſhallow reaſon—I did not tell you of it, Sir, not thinking it material enough to trouble you about.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir—then Cuckoldom is nothing material, you ſhall all out of my Houſe—you ſhall ſo, every Mother's Child of you—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What you pleaſe, Sir Paul—harkye, Bellair, there's ſomething to adjuſt between you and I, which require more privicy—follow me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So my Affair go ſwimmingly.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: What the Devil had I to do with a young Wife?

l.hi: They who in Age will drag the Marriage Chain,
Like me, they'l find the hopes of Comfort Vain;
But if Relations uſher in the Wife,
There needs no greater Curſe to Human Life.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: THUS far, Sir, I have had a ſtrict regard to the League we made in Spain—ſerv'd you in the Minuteſt, as well as greateſt things, even beyond the Character of a Gentleman in helping you to impoſe upon a Lady, making good Manners ſubſervient to my Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Prithy, Sir VVilliam, let me know the Sum at once, without this Regular Account.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: 'Twill be caſt up immediately—at your Requeſt reſign'd my own Lodgings, to oblige you, kept your Secret, even to the Woman I Lov'd—tho' you abus'd her—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, there's a falſe Tally, Sir William—I never abus'd a Lady in my Life—

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Have you not abus'd Beliza?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Which way? I never ask'd a favour that cou'd put her to the Bluſh—or promis'd Marriage, and declin'd my Word.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Have you not paſs'd by a wrong Name to her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But the Perſon is the ſame, when once a Woman likes the Man—ſhe ſeldom finds fault with the Name.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Lookye, Bellair, you may affect what Air you pleaſe—but ſupplanting my Love, and diſhonouting my Family, are things not to be repair'd with a Smile—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Diſhonouring of your Family! What mean you, Sir? Such Accuſarions are not like a Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Nor ſuch Actions, therefore Draw— (Draws.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I never Draw my Sword—till I know the Cauſe you alledge; I endeavour'd to ſupplant you; I deny it—I wou'd not ſupplant my Friend tho' I dy'd for the Woman—but this was only Gallantry—and I ignorant of your Pretences; and before I knew you Lov'd Beliza, I had fixt upon her Friend—that Point is clear'd with any reaſonable Man—but the other Article it is that ſtings me—How have I diſhonour'd your Family?—for there my Honour, Faith and Friendſhip, are concern'd—

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Are they gone, my Life—my Love—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha! my own Words!

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: And ſpoke to my Siſter, Sir—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Devil they were,

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: What! are you aſtoniſh'd, Sir? Draw inſtantly—or by the baſe Aſtront you offer'd me—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, nay, hold, hold, Sir VVilliam, for, faith, I will not Fight thee—one word—were it poſſible that I cou'd know thy Siſter by Inſtinct? Or, deny a fair Lady in Diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Trifle no longer with my juſt Reſentment—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Hear me out, and if I plead not within the Rules of Reaſon, Juſtice and Probability, paſs Sentence on me freely—ſhe's young and handſome—her Husband old and Impotent—he full of whimſies, ſhe full of Love; he wrinkled and decay'd—ſhe warm and wiſhing; I young and vigorous—ſhe Married againſt her Will—I not Married at all—We met by accident—ſhe lamented her Miſfortune—I pitty'd her—and what return ſhe might have made—no Man—not your ſelf, cou'd have refus'd,
had the caſe been yours—Oh, but then ſhe proves the Siſter of my Friend—but my Friend never told me that—Conſequently he is the Agreſſor—Now, Sir VVilliam, will you put your ſelf upon your Guard, or put up your Sword, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: My Friend, again—I confeſs thy Arguments are unanſwerable—thoſe we do not truſt, can ne'er betray us.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, your Father, Sir Thomas, has found your Lodgings, and hears you have been in Town this Fortnight—and ſwears if I don't find you out immediately, he'l ſlice me into Haſh-meat; he ſays, he ſhall forfeit a Thouſand Pound if you come not preſently—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What ſhall I conclude on—is he at my Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: No, Sir, he's upon the hunt like any Blood-hound; I run down twenty by-Ways, leaſt he ſhou'd dog me—for you know, Sir, I am your moſt careful Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: That thou art, indeed—you muſt reſolve to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And if I ſee him, there will be no avoiding this hated Match—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Without, Sir, you ſhou'd take another Name, and perſuade him you are not his Son—I have the ſame honeſt, lying Face ſtill, Sir, I'll ſwear you are none of my Maſter. (Knocks without.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, that won't do with him—ha, ſee who Knocks.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: If it be my old Maſter—what ſhall I ſay, Sir, muſt I Lye, or ſpeak Truth.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Which you will, the Condition's deſperate.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Safe, Sir, ſafe, a Letter from your Incognita, Sir: (gives him the Letter.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou dear Cordial to my Love-ſick Mind (Kiſſes it.) (Reads.) I have us'd all my Rethorick without Effect; my Father reſolves this Night to give me to thy Rival—therefore if thou haſt any Stratagem to relieve me, be quick in the Execution—We are now coming to Sir Paul Cautious's, who, it ſeems, is an old Friend of my Father's, you being in the ſame Houſe, renders you capable of ſeeing—your Incognita—now, Sir VVilliam, I'll throw off Diſguiſe, confeſs who I am, and ask her of her Father—if he refuſe, my Rival muſt meaſure Blades with me; you'l be my Second, if it come to a puſh, Sir VVilliam.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: My Sword is ſtill at my Friend's Service.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Have at him, then—I'll to my Lodgings, Dreſs, and return in an Inſtant—Now all ye Stars, that favour faithful Lovers, prevent my meeting with my Father

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And his Cane meeting my Shoulders.

div.stage: Enter Sir Paul, pulling in Lady Cautious.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: You, troop, troop—there, Sir, take your Siſter, and get out of my Houſe—do ſo—you ſhan't bring Gallants under my Noſe, and lend your Lodgings to Raſcals that wou'd Cut my Throat—mercy upon me, 'tis a Miracle the Houſe don't tumble on our Heads—I admire I'm alive—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Thou art alive, indeed, and that's all—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: All, Houſewife, why, why, why, you han't poiſon'd me, or wounded me, have you? (Looking and ſeeling about him) Baſilicon [Enter Baſilicon.] why, where are you, Raſcal? Look, am I hurt—do I Bleed any where?

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.p: Not a drop, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Can you know by my Eyes, or Hands, or any thing, if all be right within me?

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.p: Very eaſily, Sir—you are in perfect Health—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: You are ſure on't?

sp.speaker: Baſ.
sp.p: I am ſure on't, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Why then, Miſtreſs, what do you mean, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: That thou art an old Doating—Deſpicable Wretch.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hold, Siſter—better Language to your Husband wou'd become you—and for you, Sir, ſince your ill Manners proceed from groundleſs Jealouſies, Taxing a Gentleman with Crimes of which I know him Innocent—making that a pretence to traduce the Virtue of your Wife—I adviſe you to recall your Temper, and uſe her like my Siſter—or I ſhall uſe you like my Enemy.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: And run me thro' the Guts, I ſuppoſe—was ever man thus plagu'd before!

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: (Weeping,) This is the life I lead—my Vertue ſtill ſuſpected—my Innocence accus'd, and the quiet of my Life deſtroy'd—Did I truly merit his abuſes—Patience and Submiſſion wou'd become me—but I defy, even the Tongue of Malice, to aſperſe my Fame or Conduct—and do you think, Brother, I'll indure this—tamely to Submit and Cringe to what I hate.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: One word, Madam,— (pulls her aſide.) Boaſt not of your Conduct, nor your Virtue—Vile Audacious Woman—the Cloſet, Miſtreſs, think on the Cloſet.—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Does he know that? now, I'm loſt ſor ever.—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Now, Vent your clamorous Virtue—while thoſe in whoſe hands you lodge it, Echo back, you have none.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: What ſure Diſgrace attends Unlawful Love; had I really fall'n, I now ſhou'd die with ſhame.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: What are they whiſpering about, Now—contriving to make me away, ten to one, Baſilicon.

sp.speaker: Baſ.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I defy 'em to do that whilſt I am near you.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Oh, Brother, forgive me; 'twas the only ſlip I ever made—methinks I hate my ſelf, for having, but in wiſh, conſented, and grow in love with Virtue.—Since I have not ſtain'd my Family—the moſt was Thought, for ſome good Angel ſtill did interpoſe to prop my Nodding Virtue.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Take heed it nods no more.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p:
I will, for now the Shame and Ruin that muſt have attended me, are ſo conſpicious to my Sight, that I will ſhun
even the reſemblance of a Crime like this; if you'l but pardon me, I'll vow never to fall again from Duty.

sp.speaker: Sir Will,
sp.p: On that condition I do—and now, Siſter, ſince your Marriage-Knot can never be diſſolv'd, till Nature ſlips it—ſhew your ſelf the Pattern of a Virtuous Wife, indulge his Age—and that way preſerve your Eaſe, and by your Meakneſs and Humility, fix your Reputation.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I readily obey—Sir Paul, my Youth has hitherto engaged me in a fooliſh Paſſion, Contradictory to your Will, but my Brother's Inſtructions has ſo far inform'd me of my Duty, that my Behaviour, for the future, ſhall give you no cauſe for Complaint.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I'll engage my Honour for the performance of her Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Here's a turn; who can find what Plot is going forward—Are you both in earneſt now, or not?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pray, be leſs Suſpicious, and more a Man—the leſs you ſuſpect, the more you are ſecur'd, Sir Paul.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: A generous Confidence, will always oblige your Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul.
sp.p: Well, for once I will truſt thee—come to my Arms then—hold, hold, let me ſee—you have no Pen-knife nor Piſtole about you, have you?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: To what purpoſe, my Dear,—Nay, did you not ſay, you'd truſt me—

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Well, ſo I will then (Embrace.)

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Gentleman, calls himſelf Poſitive, to wait on you, Mrs. Beliza, and another young Lady, with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Bring them in immediately, I have not ſeen him this many a Year—and your Miſtreſs too Will, we'l have a Match before you part, a faith we will, my old Friend—
sp.stage: (Enter Mr. Poſitive, Beliza, Camilla, Patch and Flora.)
sp.p: Wellcome, I'm glad to ſee thee with all my Heart, Ladies, you are Wellcome—

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: Sir Paul, your Hand—I cou'd not come to Town without ſeeing you, Faith—this is your Lady, I ſuppoſe; by your leave, Madam. (Salutes her.) This is my Daughter, Sir Paul, I am come up to Marry her.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Why then, I wiſh her much Joy.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: I ſhou'd be proud of being better known to you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And I of your Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Dear Beliza, how do you expect I ſhou'd forgive your long abſence? Not ſee me in two Days.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: I confeſs my fault.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: The readieſt way to be pardon'd, is not to perſiſt in the wrong, indeed, Madam.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: But who ſhall judge between Right and Wrong?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Our Reaſon, Madam.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: That very often deceives us, eſpecially if we put too much truſt in the Perſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: It requires Judgment therefore, to make a proper choice, for every accident depends on that; but why this indifference, Madam?

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Why, that Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Becauſe Love requires more freedom.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: But Jealouſy forbids it, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will,
sp.p: Only the effect of too much Love; I ask your Pardon for all paſt Offences.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Rather of too much Folly. (Enter Belair.) Ha, Revell, at liberty again—and here, what can this mean?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ladies and Gentlemen, your Servant—Sir William, (takes him aſide.)

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Ha! the hanſome Stranger—ly ſtill my Heart, and think not of him. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Now am I diſtracted, to know whether this be her Lover, or mine. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Sir, here is a Gentleman begs leave to Unfold a Secret to you— (to Mr. Poſitive.)

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: To me—out with it then.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Has he a Secret for him too—This Spark is full of Secrets. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, I preſume you are the Father of this Lady.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: This is Conſtant, that's certain. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: So, now the Game's up—as I ſuſpected, all one Man. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: And, what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then, my requeſt is, to be admitted for your Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: For my Son-in-Law—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, provided I make it appear my Fortune, and Family are equal to yours—

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: Sir, in one word—if you cou'd prove your Deſcent from the Blood-Royal, and as many Acres of Land as the Po has engroſs'd, 'twou'd not avail you that, do you ſee (ſnaps his Fingers.) my Word's my Word, ſhe's diſpos'd off already, and ſo give you ſelf no farther Trouble.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Heart-breaking Sentence, (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is this your final Reſolution, Sir?

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: Why, Sir, what reaſon have you to believe I ſhou'd alter it?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Becauſe, Sir, I have ſome Reaſons to believe, your Daughter Loves me—and I hope you'l not force her Inclinations—

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: You have ſome Reaſons to believe ſhe Loves you—what Reaſons, Sir, what Reaſons? You have not lain with her, have you? for that is the ſureſt reaſon a Man can build upon.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You Surpriſe me, with your Queſtion, Sir,—and make me bluſh, to hear you give utterance to a thought like that—Your Daughter's Virtue needs no guard againſt ſuch foul advances.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: I hope not—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I ne're ſhall give you Cauſe, to doubt my Virtue, Sir, and 'tis unkindly urg'd—I own, I Love this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: What, this is he, that you have pick'd up ſince you came to Town, is it?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: This is he, that ſav'd my Life, Sir—and if I have him not, I ne're can love another; yet your Commands ſhall fix me as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Well ſaid.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: As to your Love, and Liking, that's out of my Power, but your Portion and Perſon are not—ſo whether you conſent or not, 'tis the ſame thing—look ye, my word's my word, ſo never trouble your ſelf about that.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is it ſo, I'll not leave the ſight of her—till I ſee my Rival—and then the beſt Arm carry her.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: And, this is your worthy Friend, you have ſo often mentioned, Sir VVilliam?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: The ſame, another time I'll inform you of every thing, and hope to obtain your Pardon for him.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Nay, I'm inclining to be good Natur'd; I like his humour mightily—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But, Sir, have you no regard to the hazards which he run, to ſave my Life; had not his generous Care preſerv'd me, you had now been Childleſs in your Age.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: Humph! Why, to ſay truth, I wou'd be grateful, but I want the means—he ſays, his Eſtate is large, ſo that he's above a Preſent—and I know not what to offer him—Sir, I thank you for the Service which you did my Daughter, and had I not given my Word, I might have choſe you, as ſoon as another, but now, there's no help for't—if you'l be one of her Bride-men, you ſhall have a Favour to keep for her ſake.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: That's ſomething.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Rude unpoliſhed Monſter, (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Inſult me not, Sir,—the Favour I wou'd wear you have refus'd.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir, here's your Father will come in, in ſpight of my Teeth—or he Swears he'll have a File of Muſqueteers, and Blow the Houſe up. (aſide to Bell.)

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: What News brings Robin?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That my Father is at the Door, I muſt go and try to appeaſe him. (Goes towards the Door, and meets Sir Thomas.)

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Give me Enterance, or, I'le knock you down, you Dogs— (Enter Sir Thomas.) Where is this Graceleſs Rogue.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: (Kneeling.) Your Bleſſing, Sir, and with it your Pardon, for having thus long conceal'd my ſelf, but when you ſhall know my Reaſons—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Reaſons, Sirrah, what Reaſons have you to ſhun your Father—and a handſom Woman; come along, come along, (pulling him.) the Parſon, and the Bride, has waited this two hours, while I have been hunting you all over the Town, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And now you have found me, Sir, I cannot comply with what you propoſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: How, how's this?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There ſtands the Lady that deſtroys my Duty—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ha! What do I ſee?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now, Sir, ſhew a true Paternal Love, and force me not to Wed againſt my Will; for tho' the Lady you have choſe, ſhou'd have all the Charms that bounteous Nature gave the whole Sex—there I am fixt—and muſt, and will, refuſe her.

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: Ha! Is not that Sir Thomas Bellair?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Sayſt thou ſo—why, then, take her, my Boy; (throws her into Camilla's Arms) for this is ſhe, thy Father did deſign for thee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, Tranſport, oh, unexpected happineſs!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Oh, exceſs of Pleaſure! (they Embrace.)

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Mr. Poſitive, your Servant; there's my Son—

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: So I ſee, Sir, and am glad of it, with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now, Sir, your conſent I hope is free.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Why, this is the prittieſt turn I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I, I, I, am ſo over-joy'd, I ſhall jump out of my Skin—

sp.speaker: Poſ.
sp.p: Camilla—there take him. (calls her to him, and throws her to Bellair.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Love, my Life—my Soul's beſt Comfort—

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: I am pleas'd to ſee the Event ſo lucky.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: So am I, Love is the ſtrongeſt guard to reſtrain Liberty.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Look up, my Conſtant, and bleſs out Friendly Stars that thus have turned out Diſobedience into Duty.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, I was loſt in Rapture, the powerful Torrent roul'd too faſt, and ſinks me down with pleaſure; now no more that Name, but know thy Husband wears that of Bellair—and now, Madam, I muſt ask your Pardon too—and you my Friend, I give you a thouſand Thanks, and wiſh you, as happy in Beliza's Love—

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: I'm glad to ſee you out of Priſon, Sir; but how?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thoſe Strategems are vaniſh'd now, and I rely on your good Nature to forgive me.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Nay, Niece, I ſeldom ask favours, therefore muſt not be deny'd; you, and my Wife's Brother, muſt make the ſecond Couple.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: I muſt ſecond Sir Paul, in that Requeſt.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Compleat my Happineſs, and bear me Company.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Augment my Joys, by Crowning of my Friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Let not all intreat in vain, Madam,

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Well, Sir William, I'll run the dangerous venture of a Jealous Husband, for once; but let me Caution you, aforehand—the more you ſuſpect my Conduct, the leſs I ſhall conſult your Humour; the more you watch me, the more I ſhall ſtudy to deceive you—Leave then, your Spaniſh Airs—and put the true Engliſh Husband on, that is the only way to have a Virtuous Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Your Advice is ſo reaſonable, that you ſhall be Miſtreſs both of your ſelf, and me.

sp.speaker: Sir Paul,
sp.p: Well ſaid, Brother, thy example ſhall be my Guide, for the future; come, we'll be merry, I'm reſolv'd; who is within there? (Enter Servant.) Go to the Play-Houſe, and deſire ſome of the Singers and Dancers to come hither; I am not often in this humour, but will be merry while it laſts.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Go in my Name—they'l not refuſe me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, thou art a good Benefactor to 'em.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Ladies and Gentlemen, I wiſh you Joy, I overheard the Concluſion of your Happineſs—and to Crown your Mirth, here's a Commical Figure upon Enterance.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Mr. Wou'dbe, without his Cloths—what doſt thou deſign this for a Maſquerade, at my Weeding.

sp.speaker: Wou'd.
sp.p: Married, and to Beliza, then the good Opinion Ned ſaid ſhe had of me, is come to nothing. I find (aſide.) Oh, Sir William, I am undone for ever, Rob'd of my new Coat, that I but juſt put upon my Back, by the moſt Whimſical Strategem you ever hear'd.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Mr. Wou'dbe out-Ploted.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: How was it, prithy?

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: Why, Sir, you muſt know I had juſt made up ſuch a ſuit of Cloaths as that you have on—and was coming hither, but meeting your Brother Ned, he wou'd needs preſs me to the Tavern to give him Beveridge, ſo in we went, the Fellow that waited on us, told me I had a Cut croſs the Shoulder of my new Coat; I look'd, and found I had—he ſaid there liv'd a Fine Drawer at next Door—he wou'd draw it up in a Minute; Wherefore I gave it him, but my Eyes ne'er Encountred him ſince.

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is your Subſcription come to this, ha, ha, ha; why did not you Examine the Houſe.

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: I did, and they ſay he came in with me, and told them he was my Servant.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: And that he never ſuffer'd a Drawer to wait on him, and therefore borrow'd an Apron of them to attend us.

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: To cheat me of my Coat—nothing vexes me ſo much, as that I have not been ſeen in it, had I but made the Tour of St. James's, and both Play-Houſes, my Paſſion for it wou'd have Ebb'd to an indifference—and then—

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: That was an unparalell'd Grievance, indeed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Mr. VVou'dbe, might I adviſe you as a Friend, leave off this fooliſh Whim of Mimicking; Sir VVilliam he's a Gentleman of a plentiful Fortune, and can afford change of Cloaths for every Day; but you, whoſe ſlender Allowance from a Father's Hand, admits of no proſuceneſs—to imitate him is Madneſs.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: What a grave piece of Advice is there—well, Marriage has chang'd my Maſter already, I find.

sp.speaker: Beliz.
sp.p: I heard you was about writing a Play, Mr. VVou'dbe, I'd adviſe you to make your top Character a Sharper—you ſee they can out-wit a Gentleman; he has ſhew'd you Plot for Plot.

sp.speaker: VVou'd.
sp.p: With what Courage can I proceed with the Play, when this Raſcal is run away with the Subſcription—Well, I'll into the Country, and never ſee this damn'd Town again.

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Servant,
sp.p: The Singers and Dancers are come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Bring 'em in, come, Gentlemen, take your Hats; but you forget, Bellair—Robin is unrewarded yet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why, he ſhall Chuſe between the two Maids.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Ah, Patch!

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Me do you Chuſe?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thou tempts me, and if I ſhou'd look any longer, perhaps the Devil might be more cunning then I.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: You don't like me, then?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Look ye, Marriage is a laſting thing—if it were for ſix Months only, I might venture upon thee—but for all days of my Life—mercy upon me—thy features are too high priz'd, Furniture for Houſe-keeping, eſpecially where they muſt let Lodgings—therefore, Flora, have at thee—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Why, will you quit her for me?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: To ſhow the Extreamity of my Love, I will.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Fool, did'ſt thou think I wou'd have had thee? Doſt thou know that I have had my Nativity Caſt, and am told that I ſhall Marry a Knight, at leaſt, if not a Lord.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Oh, good Night to your Ladyſhip, then.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Well, Patch, ſtay till my Brother Dies, and I'll Marry thee, to make good thy Calculation, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Tho' you ſhou'd make me a Lady, you'd not better my fortune much by being your Wife, our Humours wou'd quickly Conſume our Eſtate;—I love fine Cloths,—fine Coach,—fine Equipage, and fine Houſe;—Your Drinking, Wenching, Gaming, and, ſoforth—that when I wanted a New Suit, in the Morning, you have flung off your Money over-Night—

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: She has hit you home, Brother, for your Jeſting.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Well, ſince we know one another's Infirmities ſo well, we'll keep as we are—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now, my fair Camilla, I am happy—theſe Arms ſhall fix my rambling Heart.

l.hi: Ungovern'd Youth, of Taſte not over-nice,
Roves thro' the various Fields of Pois'nous Vice.
Cheated with Health, they Ride thro' Pleaſure Poſt,
To Purchaſe Liberty, what er'e it Coſt.
True Engliſh like, that Idol they adore,
And fears the Marriage-Knot, as much as Galick Power.
But if once Reaſon checks the looſer Reins,
And bring ſound Judgment into play again.
Then all muſt own—
The trueſt Joy that waits on human Life,
Is a conſtant Temper—and a Virtuous Wife,
